The Phanerozoic consists of three mutually exclusive climate states: Icehouse, Greenhouse, and Hothouse. The Greenhouse is the default state, representing N70% of the Phanerozoic. It is characterized by a weak thermal mode (pole-driven deep-water formation), with little or no continental sea ice, and weakly oxic cool-water sinking near the poles. Nitrogen limitation characterizes Greenhouse oceans in which ammonium may be the dominant bioavailable form of nitrogen. The steady-state Greenhouse default must be forced to produce either of the other two states. Continent–continent collision produces the intense chemical weathering that draws down atmospheric CO2 and results in the Icehouse state that comprises 20–25% of the Phanerozoic. Icehouses have ice caps in contact with the ocean that produce icebergs and foster sea-ice formation. Sea-ice formation fills the ocean with highly oxic phosphorus-limited icewater except for a thin layer of warm surface water in the tropics. Of the 23 most conspicuous mass extinctions of the Phanerozoic (including the late Ediacaran), 4 are associated with ice-volume-related regressions, and 3 are problematic. We suggest that the other 16 mass extinctions occurred when Greenhouse climate was forced to Hothouse climate. Large Igneous Provinces (LIPs) can trigger the HEATT (Haline Euxinic Acidic Thermal Transgression)mechanism, which can force Greenhouse climate to a Hothouse climate state. The rapid, voluminous CO2 emissions of LIPs cause a series of events that result in very slow but pronounced haline-mode circulation (mid-latitude-driven deep-water formation) that produceswarmsalinebottomwater at verydry, hot subtropical andmiddle latitudes. This water upwells at the poles, causing warm and moist equable climate. Hothouse development promotes deep-sea anoxia that is generated in concert with CO2 buildup andwarming. The spread of anoxia favors reduced nitrogen over nitrate, and limited iron dust curtails nitrogen fixation. This leads to dominance of primary productivity by primitive green algae and/or cyanobacteria. Progression to euxinia that reaches the photic zone severely curtails primary productivity via poisoning, even as availability of usable nitrogen plummets. The result is eukaryotic mass extinction.We suggest that the 16 Phanerozoic mass extinctions referred to above resulted at least in part from the HEATT process. Evidence for this relationship at 11 of the most severe extinctions is convincing.Data sets for the other 5 are strongly suggestive ofHEATT-relatedmass extinction, but do not yet have enough documentation to reliably characterize them as HEATT episodes.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Five mass extinctions stand out in evolutionary history, and many more less-intensemass extinctions are evident in the record. A plethora of causes have been offered as possible explanations for Phanerozoic mass extinctions. Examples include anoxia (e.g. Berry andWilde, 1978; Wignall and Twitchett, 1996), habitat loss (e.g. Valentine and Moores, 1970), cooling (e.g. Stanley, 1988), warming (e.g. Mayhew et al., 2007; Ward, 2007), sea-level change (Newell, 1967; Hallam and Wignall,
1999), hypercapnia (Knoll et al., 1996;Knoll et al., 2007), volcanism(e.g. Courtillot et al., 1986; Courtillot and Renne, 2003), and bolide impact (Alvarez et al., 1980; Raup, 1992). More complete reviews of the broad array of proposed extinction causes have been summarized elsewhere (e.g. McGhee, 1996; Hallam and Wignall, 1997; Erwin, 2006; Ward, 2007).
We offered a systemic model for global changes in paleoclimate and paleoceanography that intensified ecological stresses before, during, and after the end-Permian extinction (Kidder andWorsley, 2004). That model demonstrated strong linkages among many of the potential extinction causes noted above (e.g. anoxia, warming, and rising sea level). Since 2004, sufficient new information has convinced us that at least ten and perhaps as many as 16 of the most severe Phanerozoic mass extinctionswere caused by the samemechanismwe proposed for the extinction at the end of the Permian (Kidder and Worsley, 2004).
Both Keith (1982) and Kerr (1998) suggested systemic models that link major volcanism to oceanic and climatic changes and extinctions. Their prescient thinking, when far fewer data were available, anticipated many aspects of our model.

sections.heading: 2. Permian–Triassic update and introduction to the HEATT model
sections.text:
Much of the basis for HEATT episodes comes from the Kidder and Worsley (2004) model for the Permian–Triassic interval. That model focused mainly on the interplay among conditions that had been developing since the ending of Permian glaciation. Factors such as expansion of desert belts, climatic warming, poleward movement of forests and many more (Kidder and Worsley, 2004) served as the basis for promoting a long-term weakening of ecosystems that would make them susceptible to extinction. Several points that prompted model refinement are outlined briefly below.
Although we did suggest that Siberian Traps volcanism would have intensified some of the developing climatic and oceanographic conditions leading up to the end-Permian extinction, we did not invoke the Siberian Traps as a trigger. Wignall (2001) and Wignall and Twitchett (2002) pointed to the possibility of a direct trigger. Such a trigger is now a key part of our revised model for not only the end Permian, but also for the other HEATT episodes. The end-Permian HEATT episode was probably particularly severe not only because of the magnitude of the Siberian Traps eruptions, but also because of the long and widespread developmentof preconditions in themid–late Permian. Thepronounced ∂13C shifts that mark the early Triassic (Payne et al., 2004) were suggested to have been stimulated by continuing eruptive episodes of the Siberian Traps (Payne and Kump, 2007).
Erwin (2006) drew attention to the reinterpretation of late Permian fungal spores (Visscher et al., 1996) as being of algal affinity (Afonin et al., 2001; Foster et al., 2002). Ouyang and Utting (1990) had already suggested an algal affinity for one of these taxa (Tympanicysta) and Elsik (1999) had synonomized the Reduviasporonites Wilson discussed by Foster et al. (2002) with Tympanicysta. Afonin et al. (2001) noted that the original interpretation of ReduviasporonitesWilson was as a marine fungus. That these potentially marine algae became turned out to have beenaround for some10 million years before and leadingup to the endPermian extinction (Foster et al., 2002) led us to adjust some of our thinking on nutrients and productivity associatedwith the late Permian, particularly since other mass extinction horizons appeared to preserve blooms of primitive green algae (e.g. van de Schootbrugge et al., 2005a; van de Schootbrugge et al., 2007).
The Papineau et al. (2005) long-term summary of ∂15N datamade us aware of increasingly frequent reports of anomalously low ∂15N atmany HEATThorizons (Fig. 6) including the recently discovered ∂15N anomaly at the end of the Permian (Cao et al., 2009). The implications of the low ∂15N are thatwith increased anoxia in the oceans (see below) ammanox bacteria promote denitrification to a much greater degree than in the modern ocean. The low ∂15N signal reflects a dominance of new nitrogenfixation by diazotrophs. Thatfixation is limited by iron delivery to the oceans. Our updated model predicts that the sharp reductions in planetarywindbelt velocity (Figs. 2, 3; Table 2)will reduce iron delivery to the oceans much lower levels than in an Icehouse climate. Productivity will be generally limited under these conditions. This may explain why much late Permian anoxia was not marked by black shale (Wignall and Hallam, 1992; Wignall and Hallam, 1993; Wignall and Twitchett, 1996). However, opportunists which can thrive on reduced nitrogen such as ammoniumwill thrive inwaters similar to the Proterozoic ones in which their primitive green-algal ancestors arose. This allows very high productivity just before and/or just after the climax of a HEATT episodewhen these primitive disaster taxa become a key factor in ocean primary productivity.
Upwelling-driven chemocline upward excursons were suggested for the terminal Permian and several other intervals (Kump et al., 2005; Riccardi et al., 2007). This, coupledwith the report of late Permian
photic-zone euxinia (Grice et al., 2005) increased attention on the possibility that euxinia in shallow waters was a possible cause of the end-Permian extinction. However, Nielsen et al. (2010) reported that the extinction in high paleolatitude sections of East Greenland precedes the onset of sulfidic conditions, suggesting that euxinia was not an extinction cause there. Algeo et al. (2008) noted that the extinction horizon in Vietnam coincides with the first of nine distinct pyrite horizons that continue into the early Triassic. They suggested that upwelling events may have been responsible for these pyrite occurrences during carbonate platform sedimentation. Given our model predictions for weakened planetary windbelt-generated upwelling we speculate that the increasingly deep-reaching cyclonic storms predicted in theHEATTmodelmayhave been responsible for the upwellingpulses suggested by Kump et al. (2005) and Algeo et al. (2008). The likelihood that botheuxinia andelevatedCO2 are important causative factors in the extinction is becoming increasingly accepted (e.g. Bottjer et al., 2008).
A coupledmodel simulation by Kiehl and Shields (2005) that ran for 900 years used a fixed boundary condition in which atmospheric CO2 was fixed at levels approximately 10 times those of modern values (3550 ppmv). Their model generated a warm late Permian world, with warm water persisting to depths of 3000 m. The sinking polar waters that dominate modern thermohaline circulation are virtually absent in the late Permianmodel of Kiehl and Shields (2005). They also concluded that CO2 was chiefly responsible for this warming, but that ocean heat transport also contributes to high-latitude warming poleward of 60° latitude. The Kiehl and Shields (2005) results are the closest yet to approachingmeasured late Permian conditions, and they are consistent with our less quantitative considerations.

sections.heading: 3. Model generalization and the importance of preconditions
sections.text:
Having surveyed the correspondence between 11 of themost severe extinctions to Large Igneous Provinces (LIPs) in the Phanerozoic (Fig. 1; Table 1), we support the suggestion of Wignall and Hallam (1993) that the volcanism generated by the Siberian Traps LIP was the likely trigger for intense warming. This trigger instigated feedbacks that propelled Earth from a Greenhouse climate into a new planetary state known as a Hothouse, which we define herein. The LIP triggering of Hothouse conditions ismost effectivewhen the precondition of a Greenhouse climate is in force, particularly when continental collisional orogeny is at a minimum.We also generalize the 2004model to suggest that the rise of LIP-induced, short-lived Hothouse conditions caused up to 16 extinctions (Fig. 1). In each case, LIPs trigger what we call HEATT (Haline Euxinic Acidic Thermal Transgression) episodes that explain why numerous extinction factors arose at those times. Beerling and Berner (2002) showed that CO2 emissions from the end-Triassic Central Atlantic Magmatic Province LIP were insufficient to account for values of greenhouse gases expected from analysis of either leaf stomate data or carbon isotopes. They suggested that release of sea-floor methane hydrates can balance the carbon budget along the lines of earlier suggestions (Erwin, 1993;Morante, 1996) for the latest Permian.Wedonot suggest that volcanism alone changes the global state from Greenhouse to Hothouse. Although methane release is a likely consequence and amplifier of warming, we contend that many more factors come into play as a Hothouse develops.
Changes in sea level have long been considered a potential critical influence on Phanerozoic extinctions since Newell's (1967) initial suggestion. Rapid regressions can seriously decrease marine ecosystem space, leading to marine extinction. Regression appears to be an important factor in several Phanerozoic extinctions (Fig. 1). The Hawke Bay (Toyonian) event (Hallam and Wignall, 1997) and the SPICE event (Saltzman et al., 2000a) are two Cambrian examples, although some work on the SPICE suggested a transgression at that horizon (Saltzman et al., 1995). Onset of the latest Ordovician glaciation and the associated sea-level drop have long been implicated in the first pulse of end-Ordovician extinction (e.g. Hallam andWignall, 1999). The
end-Mississippian extinction has been suggested to be linked to cooling and sea level drop as Gondwanan glaciation intensified (e.g. Saunders and Ramsbottom, 1986; Stanley and Powell, 2003). However, Hallam and Wignall (1997) suggest that mid-Carboniferous extinction is more localized and selective than most mass extinctions, and Powell (2005) reported that brachiopod extinctions were mainly at tropical paleolatitudes. That it appears more conspicuous in the Sepkoski (2002) database (Fig. 1) is perplexing. Controversy surrounds the terminal Eocene extinction in terms of its duration and cause (see Hallam and Wignall, 1997). Our only point here is that rather than coinciding with transgression and warming, this enigmatic extinction occurs during a time of cooling and regression (Fig. 1). The end-Pennsylvanian andend-Jurassic extinctions are even lesswell understood than theendMississippian and end-Eocene crises, and are not considered further herein. The end-Guadalpian extinction has been attributed to regression (e.g. Hallam andWignall, 1997), although recent work (Retallack et al., 2006; Wignall et al., 2009a) suggests rapid transgression at certain key extinction localities. Rapid regressions that are glacioeustatically driven will not only be accompanied by the cooling that drives sea level down as ice sheets form, but also oceanographic changes in state of oxygenation and nutrient balance will also affect many taxa that are adapted to different conditions. Transgressions may also result in
changes in oceanic oxidation state, nutrient cycling, and other factors. However, in order to trigger mass extinctions, transgressions and regressionsmust be rapid enough to prevent life from adapting.Waxing and waning glaciers drive rapid shifts in sea level, but mass extinctions during Icehouse intervals seem to result only during regressive phases (Fig. 1). Themajority of Phanerozoicmass extinctions (Fig. 1) do appear to coincide with fairly rapid transgressions (Newell, 1967; Hallam and Wignall, 1999). These transgressions do not appear to have been driven byglacioeustatic changes because of a lackof significant ice caps at those times. Furthermore, tectonic factors were probably too slow to drive such transgressions. Kidder andWorsley (2004)made the case that the rapid transgression that extended across the Permo-Triassic boundary was driven by thermal expansion of oceanwater. Such a changewas the result of catastrophic warming at the close of the Paleozoic. Linkage between anoxia, transgression, and warming has been noted for other horizons (e.g. Jenkyns, 1980; Arthur et al., 1987; Summerhayes, 1987; Hesselbo et al., 2004), particularly at oceanic anoxic event horizons. The cause of those transgressions has not often been discussed, although Kerr (1998) invoked transgression via seawater displacement during formation of oceanic plateaus. In recent years, the coeval occurrence of additional factors such as nutrient crises, calcification crises, photiczone euxinia, and more have prompted us to expand the scope of the
model developed for the Permo-Triassic boundary and apply it to these other horizons.
Large Igneous Provinces (LIPs) have been suggested as a significant extinction driver by some workers (e.g. Courtillot and Renne, 2003). Some have focused on the short-term catastrophic effects such as emissions of ash and sulfate (Courtillot et al., 1986). Others have looked more at the longer-term systemic effects as slower causes of extinctions (e.g. Kerr, 1998; 2005;Wignall, 2001). That LIPs coincide or nearly coincidewithmanyextinctions in the record (Fig. 1) tempts consideration of these events as serial extinction culprits through Earth history. Both Wignall (2001) andWhite and Saunders (2005) point out that although temporal coincidence between LIP and extinction appears reasonable at some horizons, there are others where the relationship seems not to hold. However, our current compilation of more recent data (Fig. 1) suggests stronger temporal linkages than reported in some recent summaries.
We hypothesize that the HEATTmodel accounts for a style of global catastrophic change that is a more likely cause for many Phanerozoic extinctions than either impact or short-term volcanic effects. Crowley andNorth (1988) drewattention to the possibility of gradual changes in theEarth system leading to abrupt climate changeswhenkey thresholds were crossed. They went further to suggest that such changes might be responsible for some extinctions. In support of that conceptwe propose that the HEATT episodes are examples of Earth switching from one fundamental state (Greenhouse) to another (Hothouse) following a
series of climatic/oceanographic steps. The HEATT model unites the climate change model for initiating the thermal-expansion-driven transgression across the Permian–Triassic boundary (Kidder and Worsley, 2004) with the Siberian Traps LIP as a trigger of, rather than an accessory to, the climate change. In this updated model, the LIP initiates atmospheric warming that leads to a change in ocean circulation. That change manifests itself as what Zhang et al. (2001) called the halinemode of ocean circulation (Fig. 2). The halinemode generates warm saline bottom water that heats the ocean enough to result in a thermal-expansion-driven transgression. In addition to intense warming, other factors such as anoxia and euxinia, hypercapnia, and ocean acidification likewise intensify aspart of the interlinked aspects outlined in the HEATT model. Additionally, changing nutrient availability significantly affects the base of the food webs, and bioassimilation of nitrogen is hampered by sulfide scavenging of key transition metals such as Fe and Mo (e.g. Glass et al., 2009). Many other feedbacks are involved with this fundamental alteration of the climate shift, but each of those already mentioned here should contribute significantly to extinction. We apply this model through the Phanerozoic and suggest that it has application at least the following horizons (Table 1): 1) early Cambrian Sinsk (Botomian) event, 2) end Ordovician transgression, 3) late Devonian (Frasnian–Famennian), 4) end Permian, 5) end Triassic, 6) Toarcian, 7) Aptian, 8) Cenomanian–Turonian, 9) end Cretaceous (weak HEATT; large bolide), and 10) Paleocene/Eocene Thermal Maximum (PETM). sections.heading: 4. Fundamental changes in planetary state: Icehouse, Greenhouse, and Hothouse
sections.text:
We suggest that Icehouse, Greenhouse, and Hothouse are unique and mutually exclusive planetary states that are distinguished by more than just temperature. Each state is marked by fundamental differences in atmospheric and oceanic circulation. Kidder and Worsley (2004) reviewed and modeled the changes from an Icehouse in the Carboniferous and early Permian to a Greenhouse in the late Permian that then warmed rapidly at the very end of the Permian to a Hothouse that persisted through the early Triassic. The differences between the three climate states are generalized and formalized herein, and a significant addition is the employment of Large Igneous Provinces (LIPs) as triggers for pushing a Greenhouse into a Hothouse state. The LIP is also postulated to be a key factor in perpetuating the Hothouse state, which is otherwise unstable without maintenance of high atmospheric CO2 levels (Kiehl and Shields, 2005). Sustained LIP activity was recently implicated as a key factor in driving multiple pulses of greenhouse gas release in the early Triassic (Payne and Kump, 2007).
Although many factors and feedbacks are involved in shifts among the three planetary states, we suggest that the style of thermohaline circulation in each planetary state is critical to setting up many of the feedbacks that are exemplified by that state. Below, we define the three possible climate states according to their unique styles of thermohaline circulation. We then discuss the likely triggers for each state, and consider the feedbacks that result from its thermohaline style.

sections.heading: 4.1. The three planetary states
sections.text:
We consider the Greenhouse state to be the default state for the Phanerozoic (Table 2). More than 70% of the Phanerozoic appears to have been in Greenhouse mode. About 20–25% of the Phanerozoic was in Icehouse mode, and that climate was probably orogenically forced. Hothouses, presumably forced by LIPs, characterized less than 4% of Phanerozoic time. The forcing effects of LIPs were unable to generate Hothouse conditions during major Phanerozoic Icehouses, probably because they were not potent enough to overpower the strong thermohaline sinking of cold polar waters (thermal mode of Zhang et al., 2001). Such “thermal mode” circulation is sustained in Icehouse climates by the intense silicate weathering generated by continental collision orogenies (e.g. Chamberlin, 1899; Raymo, 1991). Table 2 and
Figs. 2–4 illustrate the unique aspects of Icehouse, Greenhouse, and Hothouse planetary states. Fig. 5 focuses in depth on the key steps involved in the changeover from a Greenhouse to a Hothouse.

sections.heading: 4.1.1. Icehouses
sections.text:
Icehouses (Figs. 2–4; Table 2) aremarkedbyextensive polar ice caps, significant alpine glaciation, and a strong ocean thermocline. The polar ice caps drivemodern-style thermohaline circulation via what Zhang et al. (2001) defined as the thermal mode of ocean circulation. Freezing polar oceanwater into ice expels salt. The resulting sinking cold brine is a key driver of thermohaline circulation in an Icehouseworld suchas the modern one (Colling, 2001; Charrassin et al., 2008). The thermal mode in the Icehouse is stronger than that in the Greenhouse because of the vastly greater abundance of ice to drive polar Icehouse sinking. The oxygen-rich sinking brines result in highly oxic bottom water in Icehouse oceans because high gas solubility and high photosynthetic productivity in polar waters keeps the bottom-water producing surface waters rich in dissolved oxygen.
An important precondition for Icehouse development is major continental collisional orogeny (e.g. Chamberlin, 1899; Raymo, 1991) (Fig. 1). The silicateweathering that characterizes suchmajormountain building events stimulates global cooling. For example, the exposure of fresh, unweathered silicate rock leads to direct removal of atmospheric carbon dioxide as carbonic acid in rainwater reacts with the silicates (e.g. Chamberlin, 1899; Walker et al., 1981; Moore and Worsley, 1994; Worsley et al., 1994; Berner, 2004). That the same weathering releases nutrients that stimulate photosynthesis. Also released are transition metals, particularly Fe and Mo that contribute to N-fixation, but also play a significant role in bioassimilation of nitrogen (e.g. Glass et al., 2009). Copper and nickel also contribute in this regard (Glass et al., 2009), but we focus our discussion herein on Fe and Mo. In terrestrial systems, much of the carbon drawn down by either silicate weathering or photosynthesis has strong potential to return to the atmosphere. Obvious exceptions are carbon burial in lakes, soils, and coal swamps. The carbon that reaches the ocean can be recycled as well, but Icehouse conditions favor enough burial to promote global cooling. High poleequator thermal contrasts in Icehouse climates promote high planetary windbelt speeds that result in extensive delivery of windblown dust to oceans (Martin, 1990; Johnston and Alley, 2006). Dust production is maximized during Icehouse climates as a result of glacial grinding of rocks. This dust bears iron coatings that stimulate diazotrophic (Nfixing) bacteria to fix nitrogen. Phytoplankton take advantage of the resulting nitrate and increase the ratio of carbon burial to recycling. The highwind speeds also foster strong upwelling that recycles nutrients so as to stimulate productivity and bury yet more carbon. Continental

sections.heading: 4.1.2. Greenhouses
sections.text:
Greenhouses (Figs. 2–4; Table 2) arewarmerworlds than Icehouses, characterized by weaker thermoclines. They may have some alpine glaciation and at least seasonal sea ice in polar regions. Major icebergproducing polar glaciation, however, is not evident in Greenhouse worlds. Nevertheless, the predominance of oxygenated oceans in Greenhouse climates suggests sufficient ventilation to keep deepoceans oxic. Thermalmode ocean circulation is therefore likely in such aworld, but it probably weakens substantially as Greenhouse conditions move toward a Hothouse state. Such circulation was proposed for the late Permian Greenhouse (Kidder andWorsley, 2004), and was successfully modeled by Kiehl and Shields (2005). Arthur et al. (1987) suggested the expansion of the oxygen-minimum zone during the Cenomanian– Turonian oceanic anoxic event. Chamberlin (1906) andWilde and Berry (1982) suggested that sucha zone is a likely destination for evaporationgenerated brines that deliver warmth to intermediate-depth ocean waters. We suggest that such conditions that begin in a Greenhouse climate can rapidly evolve into a Hothouse climate as warming drives a transgression. A weak thermal mode would greatly reduce the sinking and oxygenation of polar surface waters to the sea floor. A concurrent feeding of the oxygen-minimum zone with low-oxygen waters generated by mid-latitude evaporation would favor expansion of the oxygen-minimum zone. This would lead to greatly reduced oxygen at depth, and the likelihoodofwidespreadanoxia. The linkbetweenanoxia
and weak ocean circulation and/or ocean stratification has often been emphasized (e.g. Fischer and Arthur, 1977; Jenkyns, 1980; Arthur et al., 1987; Schlanger et al., 1987; Jenkyns, 2003). Sluggish Greenhouse thermohaline circulation produces long deep-water residence times (Kidder and Worsley, 2004; Kiehl and Shields, 2005), resulting in increased anoxia. Anoxia that does not progress to euxinia keeps iron and ammonium in solution, and so favors diazotrophs and ammoniumloving primary producers such as green algae in areas where anoxia occupies the photic zone. Retention of Fe and Mo in solution favors bioassimilation of N. We suggest that when pushed to extremes by LIP eruptions, such conditions resulted in the oceanic anoxic events (OAEs) in the Mesozoic and Paleozoic. We view OAEs as an initial step in the development HEATT episodes and as a condition likely to return after the HEATT climax (Fig. 5). In other words, OAEs can be considered a transitional phase between Greenhouse and Hothouse conditions.
Triggers for initiating a Greenhouse state have not been as widely discussed, perhaps because they are unnecessary. The Greenhouse state seems to have been the norm for much of the Phanerozoic. As noted above, Greenhouse climates persisted for over 70% of the Phanerozoic (Table 2), and they represent the default climate state that requires impetus to propel it to either an Icehouse or Hothouse. Kidder and Worsley (2004) suggested that the transition from Icehouse to Greenhouse during the Permian was chiefly a result of the waning of the orogeny that produced Pangea. Because reduced orogenic activity yields a lower volume of readily weatherable silicates, burial of atmospheric carbon should be diminished given the lesser production of carbonates and nutrients that favor organic carbon burial. The shift from Icehouse to Greenhouse may thus simply result from shutdown of the active
mechanism that initiates and maintains the Icehouse. In the case of the Cenozoic and Permo-Carboniferous Icehouses, this was probably continental–collisional orogeny.

sections.heading: 4.1.3. The Hothouse
sections.text:
The Hothouse (Figs. 2–4; Table 2) is a planetary statemarked by icefree polar regions, and weak oceanic haloclines (Kidder and Worsley, 2004). In the absence of sinking cold brine drivenbypolar ice formation, the Hothouse ocean is characterized by the haline-mode thermohaline style described by Zhang et al. (2001). Sinkingmid-latitude brines drive deep-ocean circulation in a Hothouse (Fig. 2). Warm saline bottom water (WSBW) (e.g. Chamberlin, 1906; Stommel, 1961; Keith, 1982; Brass et al., 1982) results from this mechanism. Generation of WSBW is especially effective where mid-latitude coastal embayments and marginal seas (e.g. Mediterranean), in which salinity can be elevated, deliver brine to the deeper ocean as governed by sub-pycnocline circulation dynamics (Fig. 3).Warmbrines tend to form in downwelling (e.g. anti-estuarine) areas where nutrient replenishment is minimal. Consequently, such waters are low in productivity and photosynthetic oxygenation.Adding in the gas loss fromwarmwaters, thesewaterswill be lower in dissolved oxygen thanmore oxygenated polarwaters. These sinking warm brines will supply less oxygen and fewer nutrients to the deep sea than the oxygen- and nutrient-rich brines that sink in polar
regions of Icehouses.Warm saline bottomwater generation increases as subtropics and mid-latitudes become less cloudy owing to lower relative humidity (Kidder and Worsley, 2004). Kump and Pollard (2008) suggest that lower productivity would contribute to cloud cover reduction via a decrease in biogenic cloud condensation nuclei. As midlatitude Hothouse waters sink, they also deliver sulfate to anoxic deep waters. Anoxic deep waters then reduce the sulfate to sulfide, and euxinia expands as theHothouseworld develops. Euxinia sets up a oneway shuttle system in which reduced iron precipitates as pyrite framboids in the water column (Wilkin et al., 1996; Wilkin and Barnes, 1997) that sink to the bottom. Molybdenum is also removed from solution, and it accumulates in anoxic and euxinic shales (e.g. Anbar and Knoll, 2002; Algeo, 2004; Arnold et al., 2004). Thus, Hothousewindbeltdriven upwelling fails to supply iron to the bacteria that require it to fix nitrogen, making the surface ocean dependent on greatly-diminished windblown dust for its iron supply.
Zhang et al. (2001) suggested that the haline mode was unstable in their partially coupled model, and thought it could not persist for any considerable duration. Contrastingly, fully coupled modeling by Kiehl and Shields (2005) showed that their steady-state mode (=haline mode) was sustainable for the upper 2 km of the ocean under high CO2 conditions. However, after that model reached steady state, a small patch of Gondwanan ice remained to feed the deep sea (b2 km deep)
water at∼4 °C, thus keeping the deeper ocean in the thermalmode. This inferred icemaybeanartifact of coupledmodeling that still has not been resolved (J. Kiehl, personal communication). We will give our reasons later as towhywebelieve that ice is totally incompatiblewith thehaline mode. We suggest that the rapid CO2 input from Large Igneous Provinces can tip the world from a Greenhouse to a Hothouse state as warming and drying in mid-latitudes switches deep-ocean circulation from a thermal to a halinemode.We also suggest that the initial plumeheaderuptions of LIPs are a sustaining factor forHothouseworlds.When plume-head activity of LIPs wanes, the Hothouse planetary state reverts to the default Greenhouse state. Because Hothouse climates associated with Phanerozoic LIPs are always hot, we postulate (as did Wignall, 2001) that the warming effects of LIP-generated greenhouse gases outweigh the short-term cooling influences of particulates and sulfates. However, thewarming LIP effect is negatedwhen continental collisional orogeny is sustaining amajor glaciation and thermalmode (Zhang et al., 2001) thermohaline circulation such as that of the Cenozoic or PermoCarboniferous. For example, Cenozoic Icehouse LIPs such as the large Afar and relatively small Columbia River outpourings had lesser impact than LIPs initiated during Greenhouse climates (Fig. 1).

sections.heading: 4.2. Other major differences among planetary states
4.2.1. Wind
sections.text: Wind velocity, wind shear, and wind erosive power differ markedly between Icehouse, Greenhouse, and Hothouse states. This is because a key thermal difference among the three states is the pole-equator thermal gradient (Fig. 2; Table 2). This contrast is strongest for Icehouses and weakest in Hothouses. The linkage between thermal contrast and wind is quantifiable to some degree (e.g. Wells, 1997). Kidder and Worsley (2004) assumed a value of 1.0 as a starting point in Icehouse climate for comparing aspects of wind among planetary states. By noting that planetary windbelt speed is proportional to pole-equator thermal contrast (Wells, 1997), they derived a drop inwindbelt speed of one-sixth from Icehouse toGreenhouse and a decrease of one third from Icehouse to Hothouse (Fig. 2; Table 2). Because wind shear is proportional to the square of wind velocity, sharper reductions are evident there (Fig. 2; Table 2). A new factor not considered by Kidder and Worsley (2004) iswinderosive power,which is proportional to the cube of wind speed. This relationship means that wind erosive power (and hence dust transport) could be reduced by more than 40% when changing from Icehouse to Greenhouse (Fig. 2; Table 2). The total reduction in wind erosive power from Icehouse to Hothouse is 70%.

sections.heading: 4.2.2. Nutrients
sections.text:
The sharp differences in planetary windbelt velocity have profound implications for nutrients, and hence life, among the three planetary states. If winds and surface currents weaken, then planetary windbeltforced upwelling will likely diminish from Icehouse to Greenhouse to Hothouse, although local dynamicsmight still allow for someupwelling areas. More importantly for the open oceans though, the severe loss in wind erosive power from Icehouse to Greenhouse to Hothouse will sharply reducedeliveryof eolian irondust to the oceans. Thismeans that the iron-obligate diazotrophs (N-fixing bacteria) will be seriously curtailed as they become dependent upon upwelling dissolved iron from anoxic (but not euxinic) sub-pycnocline waters. Such iron is available in Greenhouses, but not Hothouses. Saltzman (2005) used carbon isotopic patterns to infer switches in nutrient limitation between Icehouse and Greenhouse paleoclimates. He did not distinguish the Hothouse world, so these are, by default, lumped into the Greenhouse data sets. Saltzman's (2005) results suggest that Icehouseoceans tend to be phosphorus limited whereas Greenhouse oceans are nitrogen limited. Given the likely shortages of iron in surface waters because of reductions in dust input, we suggest that the nitrogen-limited oceans of the Hothouse state were stressed by iron limitation that prevented diazotrophic bacteria from fixing sufficient nitrogen to sustain produc-
tivity. Alternatively, anoxic oceans that do not become euxinic will recycle dissolved iron fromdeeperwaters. This abundant dissolved iron will cause diazotrophs to fix considerable amounts of reduced nitrogen such as ammonium and nitrite. This Fe and accompanying Mo will facilitate bioassimilation of N (Glass et al., 2009). Given that some phytoplankton are more productive when using reduced nitrogen instead of nitrate (e.g. Litchman, 2007), it becomes unsurprising to see extensive accumulation of organic-rich shales when both high surface productivity and high preservation potential in deeper anoxic waters coincide (e.g. Arthur et al., 1987; Kuypers et al., 2004). We predict that this coincidence of high surface productivity and strong preservation potential inmore acidic carbonate-dissolving deeper anoxic waters will bemaximized during the transition into and out of (but not during) the peak of the Hothouse state (Fig. 5).
Factors other than wind and upwelling will affect nutrients among the planetary states. Because of the substantial amounts of fresh, unweathered rock generated by continental–collision orogenies, Icehouse oceans will receive and retain more nutrients from silicate weathering than either Greenhouses or Hothouses. The two warmer states will havemore favorable weathering conditions because they are warmer, but Icehouse will remain the most effective nutrientgenerating state because of more silicate weathering in that state. This is so for three reasons: 1) Icehouses will be marked by more weatherable silicates because of the orogenic activity that generates them, 2) glacial grinding and mechanical weathering will break down silicates so as to increase weatherable surface area, and 3) Icehouse desert belts are least extensive, so dry regions that will retard chemical weathering will be minimized.
Icehouse, Greenhouse, and Hothouse oceans will differ considerably in style of nutrient limitation as well as in the tracemetals such as Fe and Mo that facilitate N fixation. For example, without glacial grinding in Greenhouse and Hothouse worlds, there will be less dust available for the already weaker winds to entrain and deliver to the oceans (Fig. 4; Table 1). The lessening of planetary windbelt velocity will weaken surface ocean currents and will decrease the intensity of wind-driven upwelling in Greenhouses and particularly Hothouses. Saltzman's (2005) suggestion of a P-limited Icehouse and N-limited Greenhouse is consistent with the expectation that the oxic nature of an Icehouse ocean readily returns nitrate from deeper waters to the photic zone via strong planetary windbelt-driven upwelling, and that strong Icehouse winds deliver ample iron dust to oceans to assure abundant N-fixation by photosynthetic bacteria. Ready availability of Fe facilitates abundant N fixation and bioassimilation, as does the abundance of Mo in an oxic ocean (e.g. Anbar and Knoll, 2002; Glass et al., 2009). The ability to fix N to nitrate in the Icehouse easily relative to Greenhouses and Hothouses helps to keep Icehouse oceans P-limited, but productive.
The weakened wind delivery of Fe dust in Greenhouse climates is compensated for to some degree by upwelling of recycled Fe from the thick O2-minimum zone (Fig. 4). Despite this offset, Greenhouse oceans will not be P-limited for three other reasons. First, P becomes more soluble under reducing conditions (e.g. Hotinski et al., 2000). Second, the bacterially driven anammox (anaerobic ammonium oxidation) reaction is a particularly effective destroyer of bioavailable nitrogen under reducing conditions (Dalsgaard et al., 2003). Anammoxwould be especially important in Greenhouse oceans characterized by a thick and widespread oxygen-minimum zone. Third, Mo abundance in the more common anoxic waters of the thick O2-minimum zone would fall, reducing N fixation.
Hothouse oceans would be highly depleted in bioavailable nitrogen. Not only would iron input be even more greatly reduced as winds weakened (Table 2), but also the reduced iron common to Greenhouse anoxic zoneswould be scavenged by sulfide in euxinic Hothouse oceans to form pyrite. Small pyrite framboids (≤6 μm) form in the euxinic water column, and then sink to the bottom (Wilkin et al., 1996; Wilkin and Barnes, 1997). In addition to iron,molybdenum also accumulates in
euxinic oceans (Anbar and Knoll, 2002; Arnold et al., 2004) so much so that Algeo (2004) has suggested that transition metals (including Mo) are drawn down from the ocean reservoir during anoxic and euxinic intervals.
The diminished supply of Fe and Mo in anoxic and euxinic oceans of Greenhouses and Hothouses impact life not only by curtailing N fixation, but also by sharply reducing N assimilation by life (e.g. Anbar and Knoll, 2002; Glass et al., 2009). Thus, even if residual nutrients remained in oceans as a Greenhouse shifted into a Hothouse via a HEATT episode, the scarcity of Fe and Mo would sharply limit the capability of life to use what little N was likely to be available. Furthermore, given that cyclonic storms may well be the most effective Hothouse upwelling mechanism (see later discussion) and that such upwelling would likely be drawing up poisonous sulfidic waters, extinction in Hothouse climates becomes unsurprising.
With Fe, Mo, and N governing productivity so effectively at HEATT horizons, the role of phosphorus becomes interesting. Hotinski et al. (2000, 2001) suggested that phosphorus concentration was high in deep waters like the late Permian ocean because phosphorus regenerated from bottom sediments (Ingall et al., 1993; Van Cappellen and Ingall, 1994) remains in solution in reducing waters. Another reason for high dissolved phosphorus is the iron-limited conditions described above. With productivity already low, and with iron and nitrogen serving as the limiting nutrients, phosphorus would seemingly be in excess. Counterintuitively, the phosphorus excess coincides with the phosphorite gap that marks the long early Triassic HEATT interval (Trappe, 1994, 1998). The end-Permian extinction eliminated the biological/fecal mechanism that locally concentrates it to phosphorite in Icehouses and Greenhouses. Similar phosphorite gaps are expected at other HEATT horizons, but such gaps may be difficult to detect if the HEATT episode is short. When biological productivity is high, such as beneath an upwelling zone, significant phosphorite deposits tend to be nodular or bedded (Cook and McElhinny, 1979; Follmi, 1996) indicating concentration bymetazoan activities. Most of these are likely the result of burial of phosphate-rich fecal material that may have been further enriched by phosphate mineral replacement of carbonates (e.g. Ames, 1959) or by precipitation of cements that nucleate on skeletal material during diagenesis in the top few centimeters of organic-rich sediment beneath upwelling zones (e.g. Burnett, 1977; Kidder, 1985). Phosphorite (oregrade phosphate deposits) presence reflects significant usage by biotas when productivity is high. Therefore, it is likely that metazoanconcentrated phosphorite should largely be absent at HEATT-related extinction horizons despite relatively high oceanic phosphorus concentration. However, other non-phosphorite phosphate types may accumulate as phosphorus concentration gets high enough for direct precipitation, for example as primary oolites. Primary oolitic phosphatic coatings are known from the early Cambrian (Swett and Crowder, 1982) when seawater phosphate concentration is thought to have been higher. Primary phosphatic oolites are also present at the close of the end-Triassic HEATT episode (Wignall et al., 2007). We speculate that inconspicuous disseminated phosphate precipitates should characterize HEATT-episode sediments. Perhaps the optimum place to look for such inorganic phosphates is just after the HEATT episode when oxygen becomes more available, facilitating removal of “excess” dissolved phosphorus. The end-Triassic phosphate oolites described above (Wignall et al., 2007) are in the regressive sediments just following the transgressive phase that marks the HEATT episode.
The tendency of dysoxic to anoxic oceans of the Greenhouse and Hothouse worlds will favor reduced nitrogen forms such as ammonium (NH4+) rather than themore oxidized nitrate (NO3−) of Icehouse surface waters. This will leave a distinctive signal among primary producers, in the sterane biomarkers (Schwark and Empt, 2006), and in the ∂15N record (Fig. 6). Green algae such as prasinophytes will be more prevalent when nitrogen is in reduced form because they are more effective at using reduced N than are plankton with red-algal affinities
such as diatoms, dinoflagellates, and, to a lesser extent, coccolithophorids (e.g. Litchman, 2007). Although modern plankton with red-algal affinities actually are more productive in ammonium-bearing waters than in nitrate-bearing ones, green algae are even more adept at using reduced nitrogen, and therefore proliferate. The advantage that redalgal plankton have in oxic waters is that, unlike their green-algal counterparts, they can use nitrate effectively. Presumably, the advantage held by green algae arose in NH4+-bearing waters arose when they evolved in Proterozoic and/or early Paleozoic anoxic oceans. Ammoniumwasmore available than nitrate then, so when oceans revert to that more primitive anoxic chemical state, the green algae thrive. A number of extinction horizons bear this out by preserving abundantmicrofloras dominated by acritarchs and/or prasinophytes (van de Schootbrugge et al., 2005a, b; Litchman, 2007; Prauss, 2007).
Sterane biomarkers display a shift in C28/C29 ratio that rises from lower values of less than0.4 in theearly Paleozoic tomore than1.3 in the Cenozoic (Schwark and Empt, 2006). We suggest here that the higher values reflect adaptation to nitrate assimilation in the more advanced C28-producing forms. The Devonian and Ordovician extinction zones appear to temporarily jump tomore advanced ratios, perhaps reflecting nitrate availability in oxic Icehouse oceans. Conversely, sterane biomarker values should drop at just before and after younger HEATT horizons (Fig. 5) as plankton revert to more primitive assemblages that favor ammonium over nitrate in anoxic oceans.
Nitrogen isotopes (∂15N) drop when reduced nitrogen species such as ammonium and nitrite prevail over nitrate (Fig. 6). Probably a more important driver of ∂15N is the biological selection of light values of ∂15N during nitrogen fixation. The intensive levels of N-fixation by primitive green-algal plankton that thrive on reduced nitrogen support this contention. If life is to thrive in planetary states inwhichnewdelivery of nutrients is minimized and nutrient recycling via wind-driven upwelling is also minimized, biological nitrogen fixation must necessarily increase, decreasing ∂15N levels in the process. As expected, the ∂15N values are low, and often negative near and/or at HEATT-related extinction horizons (Fig. 6). This presumably reflects high N-fixation just before and just after the extinction when iron was available via diazotrophy to thriving green-algal plankton such as prasinophytes (Fig. 5). At the extinctionhorizon, productivity is sharply curtailed as the rise of sulfidic waters cut off the dissolved iron supply. The ∂15N signaturemayhave remained at pre-extinction levels because itwasnot being used. Unused ammonium will persist in surface waters until the minimal life presentmanages tomake use of it. Suchusewill be difficult, however, as both Fe and Mo will be minimal, hampering the ability of primary producers to assimilate N (Glass et al., 2009). If annamox bacteria can survive in these waters, they will destroy bioavailable N.

sections.heading: 4.2.3. Sulfur and upward chemocline excursions
sections.text:
Positive excursions in ∂34S should characterize HEATT episodes (Table 1). Increased brine formation in evaporative basins (Holser, 1977; Claypool et al., 1980) and/or increased burial of framboidal pyrite can drive these excursions (e.g. HallamandWignall, 1997). Large inputs of volcanic sulfur from LIP activity can also contribute (Adams et al., 2010). Kidder andWorsley (2004) suggested that Hothouse conditions developing across the Permo-Triassic boundary would be consistent with both increased evaporative brines carrying sulfate to deep water and formation of abundant framboidal pyrite in the water column. Newer literature that has focused ∂34S analyses on extinctions horizons is revealing key data missed by long-term secular surveys. Positive ∂34S excursions are present in the Botomian, late Devonian, end-Permian, end-Triassic, and Cenomanian–Turonian (Table 1). Furthermore, Kampschulte and Strauss (2006) modeled biological sulfate reduction (BSR) through the Phanerozoic based on integration of ∂34S analyses from evaporites with many gaps between evaporite deposits filled by ∂34S values from new carbonate associated sulfur (CAS). Allowing for some inconsistencies in their time scale that mute the sharp positive excursions of HEATTs (their Fig. 8), their model curve for BSR is
consistent with high values during times of euxinia, including positive spikes at some HEATT horizons. Many of the low values match times of more ventilated oceans.
The framboid-producing euxinia that first developed in deeper water has been documented to rise into the photic zone during many HEATT episodes (Table 1), and we expect it will be demonstrated for others. Isorenieratane and maliemide are biomarkers that record the presence of green sulfur bacteria that photosynthesize in euxinicwaters (Table 1). Kump et al. (2005) suggested that such intervals of photiczone euxinia at the end-Permian, late Devonian, and Cenomanian– Turonian were the result of chemocline upward excursions (CUE). An important question pertaining to a rising chemocline is that of why it happens. Delivery of toxic sulfides to the photic zone should have serious negative implications for primary productivity except for the few bacteria that thrive in such waters if they can acquire sufficient Fe andMo. Kumpet al. (2005) note that CUEswouldmost likely develop in upwelling areas. Although planetary windbelt-driven upwelling would seeminglybea likely candidate,wehave already suggested that reduced wind velocity would weaken this mechanism somewhat in Greenhouses and more in Hothouses. An alternative mechanism for bringing deeper waters to the surface is one that we argue is necessary for meriodonal heat transport considerations — cyclonic storms.

sections.heading: 4.2.4. Cyclonic storms
sections.text:
Kidder and Worsley (2004) suggested that cyclonic storm (hurricane/typhoon) activity intensified as Earth shifted from an early Permian Icehouse to a late Permian Greenhouse, and thence to a Hothouse that developed at the end of the Permian and continued through the early Triassic. Kiehl and Shields (2007) showed that such
storms can persist to high latitudes in a warm equable climate. Several consequences of storm intensification are expected as Hothouse conditions are approached and achieved (Table 3). This intensification is critical for increasing atmospheric heat transport to high latitudes and for mining it from warm high-latitude waters. As planetary windbeltdriven surface ocean circulation and upwelling weakens in the Greenhouse state, increasing frequency and intensity of the storms may also be beneficial in generating upwelling of usable nitrogen and iron to
sustain productivity in the open ocean. This increased role for cyclonic storms probably explains why the black shales deposited during many oceanic anoxic events are widespread rather than being confined to predicted positions of wind-driven upwelling zones. Much of the widespread late Permian anoxia, however, is not marked by black shale (Wignall and Hallam, 1992; Wignall and Hallam, 1993; Wignall and Twitchett, 1996). With storm-generated upwelling increasing even as windbelt-driven upwelling weakens, productivity is no longer confined to weakened wind-driven upwelling zones. Instead, productivity in Greenhouse climates may correspond more closely to cyclonic storm tracks for that climate regime. However, such cyclonic storms become deadly in a Hothouse world because they reach deeper (Kidder and Worsley, 2004; Korty et al., 2008) and draw up the Mo and Fe deficient and poisonous euxinicwaters that contribute significantly to extinction.
As warmth expands poleward from the tropics, the latitudinal reach of cyclonic storms should increase because the warm waters to sustain those storms will be available in those formerly cooler-water settings. Mid-latitude storms are thought to be the main atmospheric vehicle by which heat is transported from the equator to the poles today (Barry et al., 2002). We maintain that tropical cyclonic storms have even greater heat transporting capability (Table 3), but because they are confined to the tropics in Icehouses, their importance dissipates in the middle latitudes. Positive feedback would be critical (Table 3). As storms reached to higher latitudes, they would help deliver more heat to those regions. That would, in turn, further warm higher latitude surface waters, making it more likely that subsequent storms would have an ever-greater poleward reach. Polar storms would lead also to increased polar cloudiness (Fig. 2), which would impede surface heat radiation to space, thus warming the poles even more (Kidder and Worsley, 2004; Abbot andTziperman, 2008). InGreenhouse andHothouse climates, this increased cyclonic storm activity would supplant poleward heat transport by surface winds and the surface currents driven by those winds. As planetarywindbelt velocity dropped, sowould the strength of its wind-driven surface currents. As a consequence, surface currents would diminish from their Icehouse role as important heat transporters as the world warmed. With ocean surface currents diminishing in importance in the two warmest planetary states, Kidder and Worsley (2004) suggested that atmospheric transport (latent heat and cyclones) in a warmer and more humid world as well as deep-ocean heat transport would have to increase greatly (Table 2). Such an increase would intensify total meriodonal heat transport as Earth shifted into ever more equable Greenhouse and Hothouse climates (Table 3).
The magnitude of cyclonic storms also is likely to have increased from Icehouse to Greenhouse to Hothouse (Table 3). Such increases have been suggested even for the relatively small changes in ocean surface temperature in the modern world (e.g. Emanuel, 2005). We extend this concept to the much larger surface- and deep-ocean temperature increases between the three planetary states. Evidence from increased wavelength of hummocky cross-stratified storm beds during times of highest atmospheric carbon dioxide in Mesozoic storm beds (Ito et al., 2001) supports the contention of increased cyclonic stormmagnitude in warmer planetary states. Another reason to expect cyclonic storms to increase in magnitude in Greenhouse and Hothouse worlds is because the tropical thermocline is likely to have been replaced by a weak halocline as warm saline bottomwater invaded the deep ocean (see Fig. 8 of Kidder and Worsley, 2004). Modern cyclonic storms are limited in size by the presence of the thermocline that stops their growth as theyburrow intodeeperwaters.Once theyhit those cold waters, they cannot extend themselves any deeper, and indeed tapping these waters will weaken them (e.g. Wells, 1997; Korty et al., 2008). Kidder and Worsley (2004) argued that this restraint would be weakened or removed in warmer worlds (Table 3), allowing cyclones to increase theirdepthof reach. The cyclone-magnitude governorwould be completely removed in a Hothouse and at least weakened in a Greenhouse relative to an Icehouse. Recent modeling by Korty et al. (2008) using today's ocean supports the likelihood of deeper-reaching
cyclonic storms in warmer climates. Korty et al. (2008) also evaluated the effect of storm mixing at various depths with varying water temperatures. Mixing was clearly far more effective at greater depths when model temperatures were increased. For example, if the mixedlayer model temperature is increased from 14 °C to 22 °C, the depth of storm mixing increases by 50–75 m (Korty et al., 2008, p. 651). If the mixed-layer temperature is further increased to 28 °C, the depth of stormmixing increases by an additional 100 m to a potential maximum depth of 400 m or more. Storm mining of warm waters results in positive feedback in which warming surface waters will favor cyclonic storms. In an Icehouse world, negative feedback caused by bringing up cold thermoclinewaters cools the tropics, limiting the size of the storms. This is one reasonwhy tropical latitudes inHothouses shouldbewarmer than those of either Icehouses or Greenhouses where low-latitude stormswill tend to cool the tropics. Recent evidence supports thewarmtropic scenario (Forster et al., 2007; Friedrich et al., 2008).
Cyclonic storms should be more persistent in Greenhouses and especially Hothouses because the storms will be harder to terminate in such worlds. The two things that are most likely to shut down a cyclonic storm are deprivation of heat and/or moisture. High-latitude storms that reach into deeper waters would maintain strength because the deeper waters would be uniformly warm worldwide. This is the heat-mining activity referred to earlier that is important for keeping polar climates reasonably warm and moist. Cyclonic storms in Greenhouse climates would still likely weaken or shut down in high latitudes because surface waters would be cooler there than during Hothouse and because warm saline bottom waters below the surface would not be available to sustain them as in Hothouses.
An effective way to shut down cyclonic storms in any climate, but perhaps the only one in Hothouse climates, would be for them to move over land. In the late Permian Greenhouse and the early Triassic Hothouse, vast regions of Pangea were dry. These expanded deserts would have been a most potent shutdown setting for cyclonic storms (Fig. 1 of Kidder and Worsley, 2004). However, storms that remained at sea would probably persist for long intervals. Such storms would probably have been large, as already discussed. Given the weakened steering winds discussed earlier (Tables 2, 3; Fig. 2), these cyclonic storms would probably also be slow moving (Table 3). Their slow pace would allow them to generate local upwelling of warm water thatwould serve to enlarge them.Contrastingly, Icehouse tropical cyclones weaken when they pump up cold water upon reaching the thermocline.
The increases in cyclonic storm duration, depth of storm mixing, and latitudinal reach have profound implications for nutrients and the photic-zone euxinia noted briefly earlier. If planetary windbeltdriven upwelling is weakened, the compensating increased role of cyclonic storms may go well beyond that of moving heat. Those storms would replace planetary windbelt upwelling as the major way to deliver nutrients from deeper waters to the surface. In the progression toward a Hothouse ocean, this would chiefly be ammonium (Fig. 5). Later in the Hothouse, ammonium would be depleted as euxinia removed Fe via pyrite framboids and diminished dust transport in windbelts delivered less iron to open oceans. Molybdenum would accumulate significantly in bottom sediments beneath euxinic waters, much as had been the case beneath anoxic Greenhouse waters. Hothouse cyclones would then mix the near-surface suboxic layer and deliver sulfidic waters to the surface if they were shallow enough for the storms to reach. Therefore, stormsmay be the chief reason for the chemocline upward excursions proposed by Kump et al. (2005). Suchwaters would be deadly, wiping out existing life and allowing only photosynthetic green sulfur bacteria to thrive ondiminishingpreformed ammonium.Uniformlymixed sulfidicwaters in the wake of those storms would oxidize, perhaps quickly enough to allow opportunistic plankton to capitalize on any preformed ammonium still remaining in deeper Fe-poor water that is brought to the surface.

sections.heading: 4.2.5. Sea-floor heating of deep-ocean water
sections.text: The above discussion of Icehouse-to-Hothouse upper ocean overturn and effects on tropical cyclone mixing makes the tacit assumption that all ocean/atmosphere heating is solar and so, neglects geothermal heating. This simplifying assumption is reasonable for icehouses where geothermal heating raises the lower 2 km of the ocean only 1.2 °C if only diapycnal diffusion is considered, or 0.4 °C if advection to higher (but not polar) latitudes is considered (Table 4). However Table 4 also shows that as the rapid polar sinking of the thermal mode is progressively replaced by the sluggish subtropical to mid-latitudinal sinking and polar upwelling of the haline mode, the effects of deep-ocean geothermal heating become considerable and cannot be neglected. Given the putative warming (Table 4) caused by the very long potential residence time of haline-mode bottomwaters, it is unlikely that the already-hot deep layers can remain stable. Instead, it is highly likely that the geothermal heat will serve to concentrate and accelerate haline-mode polar upwelling rather than being allowed to warm the deep ocean to the extent shown in Table 4. Such a scenario would keep the whole-ocean temperature very slightly warmer and further disrupt the already-weak pycnocline.

sections.heading: 4.3. Generation of thermal-expansion transgressions
sections.text: Kidder and Worsley (2004) suggested that the end-Permian was characterized by transgression via whole-ocean thermal expansion due to severe global warming. We generalize that conclusion here and propose that a HEATT episode is a shift from Greenhouse to Hothouse that causes a third-order transgression that is driven by thermal expansion of ocean water (Fig. 5). This transgression occurs when the sub-pycnocline zone fills with mid-latitude-generated warm brines. This deep-ocean warming drives the transgression. Alternatively, for Greenhouse oceans operating in a weak thermal mode, a transgression of smaller magnitude might result (e.g. end Cretaceous) if deep brines were cooler and less saline as modeled by Kiehl and Shields (2005) for the end Permian. Furthermore, these brines may reach down only to the O2-minimum layer, not to the bottom. Brines feeding the O2minimum zone have been previously discussed (Chamberlin, 1906; Wilde and Berry, 1982; Arthur et al., 1987), and the case forwarm saline intermediate waters has been reiterated by Friedrich et al. (2008). In addition to this, however, we believe that in a Hothouse, intense warming will also penetrate all the way to the ocean bottom (Table 3) resulting in the hallmark transgression of a HEATT episode. The HEATT transgression and the factors that lead to its development can potentially take place in less than 200,000 years if most feedbacks are positive and if the LIP trigger is strong and unimpeded by competing factors. The ∼170,000-year development of the Paleocene/Eocene Thermal Maximum (Zachos et al., 2008) is the fastest-known HEATT-like event, although it abortedbefore achieving full developmentas comparedwith other HEATT episodes. Slower (∼500,000 years) and/or stepwise transgressions may occur if the LIP trigger is weak or intermittent or is in competitionwithminor orogenic activity thatprovides enoughnegative feedback to slow and/or weaken the HEATT episode.

sections.heading: 4.4. Anatomy of an idealized HEATT episode
sections.text:
The steps involved in the HEATT episode are outlined in Fig. 5. Assuming that the minimal orogeny Greenhouse-state precondition is met, step one is the initiation of LIP activity. In addition to massive outpourings of lava, substantial emissions of particulates, sulfur dioxide, and greenhouse gases are released into the atmosphere (Kerr, 1998, 2005; Heydari et al., 2008: Pearce et al., 2008). The particulates and sulfur emissionsdonot remain in theatmosphere long(years toperhaps decades), although repeated eruptions can keep renewing these materials. Both the particulates and sulfur compounds will generate a global cooling effect by blocking incoming solar radiation, but cooling will be short-lived because sunlight-reflecting emissions will quickly settle out of the atmosphere and the sulfur will oxidize to sulfate, consumingO2 in the process.We suggest, however, that the greenhouse gas emissions will ultimately outcompete the short-term effects of particulates and sulfur because the rock record reveals warming and transgression at HEATT-related LIP horizons (Table 1) rather than evidence for cooling and regression. Greenhouse gases emitted by LIPs are probably chiefly carbon dioxide. However, in some cases such as the North Atlantic Igneous Province (Paleocene/Eocene) and the Siberian Traps (Permian/Triassic), considerable release of methane may have occurred because the LIP was erupting throughmethane-rich sediment (Svensen et al., 2004; McElwain et al., 2005; Storey et al., 2007; Ganino and Arndt, 2009). LIPs that are thereby enriched in methane might be more climatically potent than others, and LIPs erupting under such conditions might not need to be as massive as others not assisted by methane. Ganino and Arndt (2009) showed that LIPs degassing carbonate-rich strata can cause CO2 release that is disproportionate to LIP size.
Step two is further atmospheric warming. The greenhouse gas emissions from the LIP are NOT sufficient to generate the warmth that characterizes the HEATT episode on their own (Beerling and Berner, 2002). However, the warming caused by LIP greenhouse gases are probably sufficient to drive step three, which we break down into two closely-related components. One is that any seasonal polar ice that persisted in a preceding Greenhouse world is either wholly eliminated or is sogreatly reduced that its effects onocean thermohaline circulation arenullified. Theother is thatdesert belts inmid-latitude regions greatly expand their latitudinal range and get warmer as the climate shifts in response to LIP greenhouse gas emissions.
Step four consists of coeval processes operating in the deep ocean and in the atmosphere. First is the generation of sinkingwarm brines in the middle latitudes. Sinking is driven by evaporation at the expanded dry latitudes mentioned above. Such brine generation will be most effective where there are coastal embayments that can maximize evaporation and can deliver those brines across the shelf and down into the deep sea. In the absence of ice-driven sinking of cold polar brines, these warm brines become the dominant, albeit weak, driver of thermohaline circulation in the ocean. It is the replacement of polar sinkingby thesemiddle, andperhaps low-latitudebrines thatultimately drive up ocean temperatures so as to force a thermal-expansion-driven transgression. Once thermal expansion is initiated, positive feedback
sets in (Fig. 3). Evaporation generates brine which warms the deep ocean. Warmer ocean water drives transgression which expands the embayments. The enlarged embayments deliver more warm brine to the deep sea, intensifying the transgression until the loop is broken by LIP cessation or steady-state Hothouse is reached.
Step four continues as the deep ocean fills with warm saline brine. This is an effective method of poleward heat transport that partially replaces weakened winds and surface currents (Figs. 2, 3; Kidder and Worsley, 2004; Kiehl and Shields, 2005). Deep-sea bottom geothermal heat augments the process (Table 4). The atmosphere accounts for the remainder of the poleward heat transport via two processes. First, the warmer global surface temperatures entail higher saturation vapor pressure and therefore higher absolute humidity. Therefore, the lower planetary windbelt speeds are more than compensated by increased latent heat transfer, owing to the higher humidity. This moisture becomes clouds and heat-producing rain at polar latitudes (Kidder and Worsley, 2004; Abbot and Tziperman, 2008). The polar cloudsminimize heat loss to space (Fig. 2). Second, cyclonic storms in Greenhouses and Hothouseswill reach to higher latitudes, and those stormswill probably be larger and longer lasting (Fig. 2; Kidder andWorsley, 2004; Kiehl and Shields, 2005). The storms will provide even more meriodonal heat transport. Poleward flow ofwarm saline bottomwaterwill also be a key factor in delivering heat to polar regions (Kidder andWorsley, 2004 and Fig. 2). The warm water delivered to polar regions must reach the surface in order to be effective in helping to warm the high latitudes. Because it will likely bewarmer than cool (but not frozen) polarwaters, owing to geothermal heat addition, it may rise of its own accord so as to deliver heat. However, the polar surface waters will also be fresher because polar climate will have become wetter. It may be that a strong haloclinewould impede penetration of risingwarm salinewaters to the surface, causing them to upwell in slightly lower latitudes. Therefore, the extended reach of deep-mixing cyclonic storms into the high latitudes might be critical in pulling warm waters to the surface. The combined action of warm saline bottomwater, atmospheric latent heat transport, and subhalocline heatmining by cyclones ultimately serve to flatten the pole-to-equator thermal gradient to about 20 °C or less.
The timing of these steps leads to some predictions. First, organisms that are particularly susceptible to effects of rising carbon dioxide, warming and ocean acidification may begin to exhibit a record of extinction prior to the major portion of the thermal transgression and intensified warming that develops just before delivery of toxic euxinic waters into the photic zone. Corals are one example of a sensitive group in this regard. Veron (2008) outlined a stepwise progression of ocean acidification effects on coral reefs, with deep, azoothanthellate taxa being eliminated first, followed by shallow, fast-growing branching taxa, and finally bymassive corals. Devonian data do not, to date, match the predictions for reef loss either via anoxia or acidification although corals do make early departures. Devonian coral diversity underwent multiple declines before the Frasnian/Famennian (F/F) extinction (Copper, 2002). The end-Givetian extinctions for tabulates, rugosans, stromatoporoids, and reef-associated brachiopods was more severe than the F/F, and Givetian reef diversity had been substantially reduced prior to the Frasnian (Copper, 2002). Younger reefs disappeared before the F/F extinction. Copper (2002) suggested that these extinctions preceded the F/F horizon by one to two conodont zones. Copper (2002) also emphasized that the departure of Frasnian reefswasnot temporally linked with anoxic horizons, and reef loss coincided with regression rather than transgressive black shales, although the demise of latest Frasnian reefs has been linked to anoxic transgression in Poland (Bond et al., 2004). Furthermore, deep-water rugose corals passed through the extinction unscathed (Sorauf and Pedder, 1986; Copper, 2002), suggesting that neither anoxia nor acidification affected them to any great extent. It is clear that stepwise reef extinctions in the lateDevonian march to their own tempo relative to thoseof other organisms.Although pulses of transgressive anoxia consistent with HEATT predictions characterized this interval, these pulses to not appear to match reef
extinctions or the main F/F event (Sandberg et al., 2002). Both tabulate and rugose corals went extinct just prior to the main end-Permian extinction event (Knoll et al., 1996; Jin et al., 2000), although they were no longer reef formers. Terrestrial biotas might similarly record some early extinctions as the atmospherewarms and themiddle latitudes dry out. This seems to be the case for the end-Triassic extinction (Pálfy et al., 2002) and for the end-Permian extinction (Ward, 2007). We caution that the backsmearing of extinction via the Signor-Lipps effect (Signor and Lipps, 1982) must be filtered out before major significance can be attached to all precursor extinctions.
The sharply negative ∂13C excursion common to many HEATT episodes (Table 1) has often been explained by methane release (see Erwin, 1993; Kidder andWorsley, 2004; Zachos et al., 2008 for reviews). Methane release as a result of deep-oceanwarmingwould intensify the climatic warming already underway in a HEATT episode. We note here that the drop in ∂13C can also be explained by productivity loss (Berner, 1989; Broecker and Peacock, 1999) and by luxury feeding of photosynthesizers in a CO2-rich atmosphere (Galimov, 1985; Worsley and Nance, 1989). Luxury feeding can reduce ∂13C by −1‰ for each doubling of atmospheric CO2. Three such doublings, for example, were postulated by Kidder and Worsley (2004) across the Permo-Triassic boundary.
As the thermal transgression begins, changes in themarine nutrient cycle will strongly feed back into accelerating the transgression if allowed to progress to a fully developed HEATT event (Fig. 5). In this early phase of the transgression, green algae such as prasinophytes take over the chief role in carbon burial, fueled by intense diazotrophy as storms pull up reduced iron. This high productivity above anoxic deep waters will result in considerable black shale accumulation, slowing the rate ofwarming instigated by other factors discussed so far. However, as euxinia develops, dissolved iron and molybdenum become insoluble and accumulate in bottom sediments. Cyclones and any other upwelling then bring poisonous sulfide to the surface instead of beneficial iron. Productivity shuts down as anammox and photosynthesizers rapidly denitrify the remaining ammonium, removing a key restraint on the warming factors such as volcanically generated CO2 and the positive feedbacks that it triggers. Warming is now maximized, and the transgression reaches its peak at the culmination of the HEATT episode. It is possible that the total denitrification and mass extinction can precede the peak of the transgression. In that case, productivity will remain shut down until the peak transgression begins to subside. Euxinic conditions are now very close to the surface, and episodically reach the surface during storms. The HEATT episode is maintained until the LIP emissions of greenhouse gas ease, allowing theworld to revert to Greenhouse conditions.

sections.heading: 5. Applying the HEATT model to extinction horizons
sections.text:
Many of the eleven extinction horizons that we consider HEATT related (Table 1) have a number of common factors includingwarming, transgression, anoxia, euxinia, ∂13C anomalies. The end-Cretaceous and PETMdonotfit aswell as the other nine, and those discrepancieswill be discussed separately later. These factors are all specified by the HEATT model, and many of them have separately been proposed as extinction causes. The horizons are not discussed in chronological order for a reason.Mesozoic HEATT episodes are discussed first because alongwith the Permo-Triassic episode, these tend to fit the model best. The endCretaceous episode is last within that group because it is a weak HEATT episode, and it was amplified by the Chicxulub impact. Although the Botomian (early Cambrian) HEATT episode does fit the model reasonably well, the Ordovician and Devonian HEATT episodes are more complicated by their slower development and because they are both associated with brief glaciation that appears to interrupt their development. The Paleocene–Eocene Thermal Maximum (PETM) is discussed last because although we consider it an aborted HEATT episode, and access to the data that reveal the timing and quantitative
aspects of its development is considerably better than for older HEATT episodes, it remains aberrant relative to the other HEATT episodes for reasons we will discuss.

sections.heading: 6. Mesozoic HEATT episodes
sections.text: The end-Triassic, Toarcian, Cenomanian–Turonian, and end-Cretaceous as HEATT episodes are all related to major extinctions. The Aptian is another HEATT episode to which we allude, even though its associated extinction is minor. We predict that there are a number of other lesser HEATT episodes in the Mesozoic. The Albian and Valanginian are both likely contenders that we briefly introduce herein. Previous workers have already recognized linkages between some of the factors that we include in the HEATT model. Connections between widespread anoxia and/or warmth and/or marine sea-level rise have been noted (e.g. Jenkyns, 1980; Arthur et al., 1987; Schlanger et al., 1987; Kerr, 1998; Wignall, 2001; Hesselbo et al., 2002, 2004; Jenkyns, 2003; Pearce et al., 2008). Schlanger et al. (1987) termed such intervals oceanic anoxic events (OAEs). Connection to extinctions has been suggested as well (Hallam and Wignall, 1997, 1999; Ward, 2007). Kerr (1998) was even bolder, suggesting that the Cenomanian–Turonian warming, anoxia, and extinction were not only linked, but also were related to LIP volcanism, which drove the transgression via ocean plateau formation. Although ages for two LIPs (Madagascar and the Caribbean–Columbian region) appear to be too young to have initiated Cenomanian–Turonian HEATT (Wignall, 2001; White and Saunders, 2005), the Ontong–Java LIP does appear old enough (Fig. 1), and we acknowledge Kerr's (1998) prescient view and assimilate his contentions into the HEATT model. Pearce et al. (2008) noted strong connections between sharp swings in ∂13C and conspicuous changes in ocean redox at the Toarcian and Cretaceous OAEs. They also link these changes with global warming episodes. Pálfy and Smith (2000) proposed that the Karoo–Ferrer LIP triggered the changes, much like many aspects of Kerr's (1998) suggestion for the Cenomanian–Turonian OAE and its triggering LIP(s).

sections.heading: 6.1. Terminal Triassic HEATT
sections.text:
The end of the Triassic is fairly consistent with HEATT model predictions, and it appears to include two pulses of crisis. A sharply negative spike in ∂15N (Fig. 6) has been recognized (Sephton et al., 2002; Quan et al., 2008) at the base of the Rhaetian. Anoxia is well developed from this point on (e.g. Hesselbo et al., 2004; Ward, 2007; Wignall et al., 2007). Some extinction marked the end-Norian (e.g. Ward, 2007). The Rhaetian did not seemuch in theway of post-Norian recovery prior to the terminal blow to Triassic assemblages. The Rhaetian–Hettangian boundary zone is distinguished by a phytoplankton progression of dinoflagellates giving way to prasinophytes and then acritarchs (van de Schootbrugge et al., 2007). Green and purple sulfur bacteria suggest chemocline euxinic excursions (Richoz et al., 2008). A calcification crisis is suggested by thin-shelled pectinids (Wignall et al., 2007) and scarcity and dwarfism in calcareous nannoliths (van de Schootbrugge et al., 2007). This crisis has been linked with volcanic degassing leading to an ocean undersaturated in CaCO3 at the end of the Triassic (Berner and Beerling, 2007). The post-regression transgression within the boundary horizon (Hesselbo et al., 2004; Tanner et al., 2004) coincides with the negative ∂13C anomaly (Ward et al., 2001; Hesselbo et al., 2002). The CAMP LIP is the likely HEATT trigger as most recent work except Whiteside et al. (2007, 2010) puts it temporally close to the extinction (e.g. Wignall, 2001; Hesselbo et al., 2002; Pálfy et al., 2002; Marzoli et al., 2004). Warmth is evident (McElwain et al., 1999; Beerling and Berner, 2002; Berner and Beerling, 2007; Cohen and Coe, 2007; van de Schootbrugge et al., 2007), and modeling (Huynh and Poulsen, 2005) is consistent with CO2 driving that warming.
Beerling and Berner (2002) anticipated aspects of the HEATT model when they pointed out that although the CAMP LIP eruptions were massive, they could not have produced sufficient warming to drive the carbon shift. They noted the call of Pálfy et al. (2001) for release of methane hydates to drive the isotopic shift. The sinking warm brines of the HEATT model provide the connection between terrestrial warmth caused by volcanic emissions of CO2 and the release of oceanic methane that would have intensified the warming.
