The evidence for elevated CO2 is not just a modeling artifact, but arises from direct measurements of leave stomates in fossil leaves (McElwain et al., 1999).
The HEATT model predicts precursor extinctions in the terrestrial realm and in selected marine faunas affected by warmth, acidification or anoxia. The multiphase aspects of the end-Triassic extinction(s) seem evident in the reported loss of monotid bivalves at the end of the Norian at the Kennecott Point (Queen Charlotte Islands) in British Columbia as deep waters became anoxic (Ward et al., 2001). Pálfy et al. (2002) suggested that terrestrial extinctions may have preceded the marine ones, but more recent work (Whiteside et al., 2010) suggests terminal Triassic extinction is synchronous in themarine and nonmarine realms. The transgression reported within the boundary horizon (Hesselbo et al., 2004) was probably the final knockout blow during this HEATT episode. The lack of a transgression at the end of the Norian may simply mark the initial spread of anoxia during the early part of the HEATT episode. Given the two-phase nature of late Triassic development of warming, anoxia, and extinction, we speculate that there may have been an end-Norian transgression that has not yet been recognized. Hori et al. (2007) note that deep-sea sediments of the Panthalassic Ocean were oxic, in contrast to the anoxic continental margin sections discussed above. This is consistent with an expanded oxygen-minimum zone (Figs. 2 and 3) that would not reach all deep-sea sediments.

sections.heading: 6.2. Toarcian HEATT
sections.text:
The Toarcian extinction exemplifies many aspects of a HEATT episode (Table 1). It is a well-known anoxic horizon (e.g. Jenkyns, 1988; Jenkyns and Clayton, 1997; Pearce et al., 2008). It is marked by a negative carbon isotopic excursion (van de Schootbrugge et al., 2005a, b; Wignall et al., 2006). A significant rise in global temperature based on Mg/Ca ratios and ∂18O is also evident (Bailey et al., 2003). As is the case with many carbon isotopic excursions, the cause of the negative ∂13C spike has been a topic of debate. Recent review and evaluation of potential causes (Beerling and Brentnall, 2007) fail to resolve whether release of light carbon by heating Gondwanan coal (McElwain et al., 2005) or release of such carbon from oceanic clathrates (e.g. Hesselbo et al., 2000; Cohen et al., 2004; Kemp et al., 2005) can sufficiently perturb the carbon cycle to cause the sharply negative excursion. The HEATT model offers the opportunity to initiate global warming by carbon dioxide release during the Karoo–Ferrar LIP, which Pálfy and Smith (2000) and Pearce et al. (2008) also suggested as a trigger. That warming would lead to the sinking warm waters that could liberate methane hydrates from sub-sea-floor sediments, triggering the ∂13C anomaly. This, of course, calls for some warming before the excursion, and more warming as the oceanic methane is released. Although the coals called upon by McElwain et al. (2005) do not seem to be sufficient to trigger the ∂13C anomaly on their own, they could be a supplemental light carbon source. As noted earlier, luxury feeding by life can cause a drop of approximately −1‰ in ∂13C values for each doubling of atmospheric carbon dioxide (e.g. Galimov, 1985; Kump and Arthur, 1999). This should affect results obtained from both carbonate and organic matter, though the dynamics can be complex (Kump and Arthur, 1999). As with any HEATT episode, the release of carbon dioxide and methane that creates the warming that ultimately leads to transgression will also acidify the ocean. It is not surprising,
then, that calcareous phytoplankton undergo calcification challenges during the ∂13C excursion (Tremolada et al., 2005).
Although the ∂13C excursion itself lasted only about 200 k.y. (Kemp et al., 2005; Cohen and Coe, 2007), the HEATT effects may have been longer lasting leading up to the ∂13C spike. The main extinction event, however, should be rapid, coinciding with the transgression and the ∂13C spike. As predicted by the HEATT model, dinoflagellates are replaced by green algae (Tasmanites) at the boundary (Palliani et al., 2002). Van de Schootbrugge et al. (2005a) note that even though the dinoflagellates were outstripping green algae such as acritarchs and prasinophytes as primary producers in the late Pleinsbachian oxic seas, the green algae replaced the dinoflagellates when the latter disappeared at the euxinic extinction horizon (Table 1). The negative ∂15N spike at this same horizon (Fig. 6) occurs as expected. Van de Schootbrugge et al. (2005a) suggested that the redox changes were responsible for the plankton shifts. This is also consistent with a switch to ammonium-favored green algae. Toarcian euxinia (Jenkyns et al., 2007) reached the photic zone (Pancost et al., 2004; van Breugel et al., 2005) in accordance with HEATT model predictions.

sections.heading: 6.3. Early–mid Cretaceous minor HEATTs
sections.text:
The Lower Cretaceous is marked by several probable lesser HEATT episodes. Each of these shows some HEATT characteristics, but the records of these are not as fully explored as many of the other HEATT intervals we identify. The lesser amount of study is likely because these episodes are associated only with minor extinctions.
Both the Aptian (OAE 1a) and Albian (OAE 1b) are well-known anoxic intervals (e.g. Jenkyns, 1980; Bralower et al., 1994; Jenkyns, 2003 and references therein). Photic-zone euxinia has been recognized as well (Heimhofer et al., 2008). The Valanginian has recently been suggested as another OAE (Erba et al., 2004).Warming is evident at least some of these (Jenkyns, 2003), and transgression is less well documented, but likely. The Aptian HEATT episode (Table 1) occurred during the first major phase of activity of the massive Ontong–Java oceanic LIP. The Albian was probably another minor HEATT episode. The Kerguelen LIP is a tempting trigger, although it seems to have initiated at 111 Ma, just after the Albian (112 Ma) OAE. It has been argued that plume and mid-ocean ridge activity was most intense during the early Cretaceous (e.g. Larson, 1991). Such volcanismmight have lowered the threshold needed to instigate a HEATT episode, so even relatively small LIPs might serve as HEATT triggers. The Albian warming appears to have left a record consistent with increased atmospheric heat transport. Ufnar et al. (2004) suggested from ∂18O values in sphaerosiderite samples that rainfall intensified at mid and high Albian latitudes while leaving a record of a moisture deficit at low paleolatitudes. The Valanginian OAE coincides with the Parana– Etendeka LIP (Fig. 1). Erba et al. (2004) suggested that the associated positive ∂13C excursion and black shale occurrences in the Pacific and the southern Alps marked a newly recognized OAE. However, they interpreted this interval as a cooling event based on oxygen isotope records and nannofossils.
In addition to being a likely HEATT episode, the Albian OAE is suggested to have recorded a significant long-term shift in primary productivity (Kuypers et al., 2001). The marine archaea that appear to increase in importance at this time may have bearing on ∂13C patterns for the Albian that is atypical for other HEATTs. Erbacher et al. (2001) noted aminor negative carbon excursion at the baseof theAlbianOAE in the western tropical Atlantic. After discounting productivity changes as a driver of this anomaly, they tentatively suggested a CO2 degassing mechanism for the small negative spike. Methane offers another possibility. Erbacher et al. (2001) noted a decrease in ∂18O (their Fig. 1) that coincideswith the brief decline in ∂13C. They argued that this change of roughly −3‰ ∂18O was not likely to be a result of warming, because thatwould require an increase in temperature of about 10 °C in a geologically rapid interval of time. We agree with Erbacher et al.
(2001) in that the ∂18O shift need not have been entirely driven by temperature, but the negative ∂13C shift, supports HEATT initiation at the base of theOAE. Carbon isotopic values donot changemuch through the rest of the OAEwhere Erbacher et al. (2001) analyzed it. Kuypers et al. (2001) proposed that increases in ∂13C in bulk organic carbon may reflect a massive expansion of marine archaea in the Albian. It is becoming increasingly evident that archaea are no longer relegated to the extremophile niche (Herschberger et al., 1996). It may be that chemoautotrophic marine archaea are normally outcompeted by photoautotrophs in surface waters. The coincident collapse of many phytoplankton during a HEATT episode combined with bringing the chemocline into the photic zone during least 7 of the HEATT intervals (Table 1)may have allowed archaea to thrive on sulfur and/or ammonia and/or organic matter during the HEATT. Marine archaea do not isotopically discriminate in the type of carbon they use, and as a result, they can lead to positive ∂13C isotopic shifts. This may apply to other HEATTs that aremarkedbypositive ∂13C shifts such as theCenomanian– Turonian, Valanginian, and Devonian (Frasnian–Famennian). Archaea considerations aside, the positive ∂13C excursions may have a simpler explanation. The high productivity expected just prior to a HEATT climax, when abundant upwelled iron fuels intensive N fixation should generate a positive ∂13C excursion. Those few HEATTs marked by positive ∂13C excursions may simply not have fully developed into HEATT episodes, or may have done so only regionally.

sections.heading: 6.4. Cenomanian–Turonian HEATT
sections.text:
The Cenomanian–Turonian oceanic anoxic event (OAE) has long been well known (e.g. Schlanger and Jenkyns, 1976; Jenkyns, 1980; Arthur et al., 1987; Schlanger et al., 1987; Jenkyns et al., 2007). The widespread anoxia has been linked to transgression (e.g. Jenkyns, 1980; Arthur et al., 1987; Kerr, 1998; Jenkyns, 2003), and photic-zone euxina marks the interval (Kuypers et al., 2002; Pancost et al., 2004). The characteristic positive ∂13C spike (Arthur et al., 1987, 1988) at this horizon distinguishes this interval from many other HEATT horizons. However, there is a brief negative ∂13C excursion at the base of the Livello Bonarelli black shale in Italy (Jenkyns et al., 2007; Kuroda et al., 2007). Although this horizon has long been considered a thermal maximum (Jenkyns et al., 1994; Wilson and Norris, 2001; Norris et al., 2002), others have supported cooling as well (Arthur et al., 1988; Kuypers et al., 1999; Jenkyns, 2003). Recent work suggests that both occurred. Forster et al. (2007) found good agreement between TEX86 and ∂18O records suggesting that the most intense warming of tropical sea surface temperatures (to∼35°–36 °C) were achieved at the onset of the OAE, consistent with the HEATT model. Subsequent cooling within theOAEdropped the temperatureby∼4 °Cwithin theearly stagesof the OAE. Norris et al. (2002) suggested that the warming recorded in oxygen isotopes warranted the intensification of atmospheric heat transport, which is consistent with the HEATT model.
Kerr (1998) took an intuitive leap in proposing linkage between extensive ocean plateau volcanism and a number of aspects that are critical components of HEATT episodes at the Cenomanian–Turonian extinction horizon. He suggested that oceanic and atmospheric warming and widespread anoxia were a result of the eruptions, as was the transgression and the positive ∂13C anomaly. He argued that the warming was a result of CO2 release from the volcanism, and that other emissions would lead to acidic oceans and carbonate dissolution. Kerr (1998) was using an age of 90.4 Ma for the age of the Cenomanian–Turonian boundary, which was then consistent with the timing of activity at both the Caribbean–Columbian and the Ontong– Java LIPs with LIP eruptions at Madagascar and the Kerguelen Plateau occurring just a little later. The connections he suggested fell by the wayside to some extent when the accepted age for this boundary was pushed back to 93.5 Ma. Wignall (2001) and White and Saunders (2005) both noted this mismatch in timing, with the episodes at the Cenomanian–Turonian boundary happening before the eruption ages.
However, new work on the Ontong–Java Plateau suggested that its renewed pulse in activity began at 94 Ma (Fig. 1). Leapfrogging between dates of anoxia/extinction events and LIP activity may continue with further work, but the temporal connection between major volcanism and the Cenomanian/Turonian events presently appears robust. Furthermore, new results from the measurements of 187Os/188Os in black shale strongly suggest substantial magmatic activity (Turgeon and Creaser, 2008). These new results support the linkage between major oceanic magmatism and Cenomanian– Turonian boundary anoxia in a fashion consistent with the HEATT model. However, Kerr's (1998) suggestion that CO2 emissions alone drove thewarming is probably too optimistic. As we contend for other HEATTs, the initial LIP contributions were probably only sufficient to initiate warming rather than cause all of it. Switching on the haline mode was an important next step in delivering heat to polar regions. The recent estimate of the magnitude of the transgression at 22–28 m (Voigt et al., 2006) is comparable to the 20 m of thermal-expansiondriven components of sea-level rise calculated for the Permo-Triassic boundary transgression driven by haline-mode heating of the deep sea (Kidder and Worsley, 2004).
The predominant positive ∂13C anomaly suggests that methane may not have been a key factor in the Cenomanian–Turonian boundary warming. It also argues against luxury feeding. On the other hand, there are some interesting aspects to the nutrient and plankton dynamics that may have offset factors that would tend to produce a negative ∂13C excursion. Prauss (2007) noted that prasinophyte abundance dropped at the Toarcian transgressive horizon whereas prasinophytes actually become more abundant at the Cenomanian–Turonian maximum flooding surface, just above the positive ∂13C anomaly. Both the Toarcian and Cenomanian–Turonian anoxic horizons are marked by negative spikes in ∂15N (Fig. 6). The proposed expansion of marine archaea during Albian anoxia offers another possible explanation for the increase in ∂13C (Kuypers et al., 2001). If there were an increase in archaea at the Cenomanian– Turonian, it could perhaps have left a positive ∂13C signal despite negative influences such as luxury feeding or sea-floor methane. Cooling has been invoked as a result of the impressive carbon burial recorded at the Cenomanian–Turonian boundary (Arthur et al., 1988; Kuypers et al., 1999; Jenkyns, 2003; Forster et al., 2007). Although intensive carbon burial could have resulted in some cooling, we contend that cooling is inconsistent with the transgression that is clearly present and is within the range predicted for a thermal transgression cause. Another consideration is that cyanobacteria have been suggested as a strong influence on ∂13Corg in the Livello Bonarelli black shale (Kashiyama et al., 2008). If this cyanobacterial influence is strong enough, carbon burial might have been somewhat less important that much current thinking suggests. We suggest that the brief negative ∂13C shift at the base of the Bonarelli bed (Jenkyns et al., 2007; Kuroda et al., 2007) might signal quick onset of HEATT conditions. The subsequent and more conspicuous positive ∂13C excursion may simply represent intensive organic carbon burial and/ or increased cyanobacterial influence on productivity following rapid initiation of this HEATT episode.

sections.heading: 6.5. End-Cretaceous HEATT
sections.text:
Since the initial proposal of Alvarez et al. (1980), extraterrestrial impact has become the most widely accepted cause for the terminal Cretaceous extinction (e.g. D'Hondt, 2005). However, the Deccan Traps LIP has also been proposed as the causal factor (Courtillot et al., 1986; Courtillot and Renne, 2003). These massive eruptions should have generated a HEATT episode comparable to others discussed herein. However, although some aspects of the latest Cretaceous are consistent with expected HEATT activity, other key factors are less evident than during other HEATTs. What we interpret as a weakly developed HEATT that started just before the end-Cretaceous impact
(Chenet et al., 2008; Robinson et al., 2009) leaves an intriguing and complex record before, during, and after the extinction that ended the Mesozoic. A striking difference between the K–Pg extinction and extinctions during other HEATT episodes is that shallow-water organisms are much more affected at the K–Pg extinction relative to a greater emphasis on deeper-water taxa. The Cenomanian–Turonian is the next oldest horizon below the K–Pg, and this selective difference between these two Cretaceous extinctions is particularly evident (Kerr, 1998).
Two factors are consistent with a HEATT episode. The first is the presence of a minor transgression (Keller and Stinnesbeck, 1996; Adatte et al., 2002; Miller et al., 2003) that interrupts a long-term regressive pattern through the latest Cretaceous and follows a sharp Maastrichtian regressive episode (Haq et al., 1987). The second is a sharply negative ∂13C excursion that marks the K–Pg boundary (e.g. Zachos and Arthur, 1986), but this is only from the planktonic foraminiferal records (Zachos and Arthur, 1986). The deep-sea foraminifers are unaffected with respect to carbon isotopes. This sudden drop in ∂13C has been widely interpreted as a drop in productivity in the surface ocean (Zachos et al., 1989). Some workers have argued that this dramatic drop in productivity may have meant that there was a Strangelove (lifeless) ocean at this time (e.g. Hsu et al., 1982). However, Kump (1991) points out that because surface ocean productivity is a key driver of the ocean's carbon systematics, carbon isotopes in shallow and deep settings would quickly have been homogenized in a lifeless surface ocean. Because this did not occur, Kump (1991) argues that productivity would have continued on land and/or in the surface ocean at reduced rates. The calcareous nannoplankton and planktonic foraminifera underwent substantial extinction at the end of the Cretaceous. The preferential suffering of calcareous plankton at the K–Pg extinction is consistent with ocean acidification at that time (D'Hondt et al., 1994). However, the dinoflagellates weathered the extinction reasonably well, perhaps because of their ability to exist as cysts, enabling them to wait out a short-term crisis (Hallam andWignall, 1997; D'Hondt, 2005). Diatoms suffered only moderate extinctions (Hallam and Wignall, 1997).
The anoxia that marks other HEATT episodes discussed herein does not appear to be of much consequence at the Cretaceous–Paleogene boundary. Local examples do exist (e.g. Parra et al., 2003), but anoxia hardly seems to be a common theme at the boundary. Evidence for photic-zone euxinia that marks a number of other HEATT episodes is also absent. Despite a brief drop in ∂15N at the base of the Fish Clay (Sepúlveda et al., 2009), effects of reduced nitrogen influence appear minimal. The fact that thedinoflagellatesmade it through the extinction relatively unscathed rather than being displaced by primitive plankton such as prasinophytes that thrive on reduced nitrogen supports maintenance of an oxic ocean. “Red” algal offshoots such as dinoflagellates, diatoms, and coccoliths thrive in waters in which nitrate is the dominant form of usable nitrogen, so although productivity was interrupted or at least greatly reduced at the extinction, dinoflagellates, diatoms, and coccolithswere able touse nitrate during the recovery. The coccoliths, of course, were significantly reduced as noted earlier, but nutrient changes would not likely be that selective, particularly since coccoliths aremore adept at using reduced nitrogen than either diatoms or dinoflagellates (Litchman, 2007). The ocean acidification (D'Hondt et al., 1994) mentioned earlier explains this selective coccolith loss. Collectively, these factors suggest that the end-Cretaceous ocean remained oxygenated. This would argue that the thermal mode of ocean circulation remained strong enough to prevent development of a strong HEATT episode. The thermal mode would have to be relatively strong to retard the influence of massive greenhouse gas emissions expected from the Deccan Traps. Dominance by thermal-mode circulation also helps explain temperature changes recorded in the oceans.
Attention with regard to warming climate at the end of the Cretaceous tends to focus on CO2 generated by impact in and presumed
vaporization of the Yucatan carbonates at Chicxulub, whichwould have vaporized massive amounts of carbonate deposits. Leaf stomate data (Beerling et al., 2002) suggests that most of the atmospheric CO2 increase postdates the extinction. Some evidence supports warming across the boundary that coincideswith the transgression (e.g. Adatte et al., 2002). Other studies argue for a warming pulse some 300,000 years before the extinction followed by cooling across the boundary (Li and Keller, 1998; Keller et al., 2004; Keller et al., 2009). It makes more sense for a warming pulse to coincide with transgression as opposed to a regression. Furthermore, the short-term sea-level changes described by Miller et al. (2003) are reported to have been on the order of 20–30 m. This is a value of sea-level change consistent withwhat can be achieved by HEATT episodes. It is tempting to speculate that the transgression across the boundary was caused by thermal expansion of the oceans.
If the transgression was not generated by thermal expansion, the case for a HEATT episode at the end of the Cretaceous looks even weaker. However, Keller et al. (2009) noted that the planktonic foramifera found in the ∼1.5 m of strata they report between the Chicxulub impact layer and the terminal Cretaceous in Texas are dwarf species able to tolerate low-oxygen conditions. This could be a weak signal of dysoxic waters that developed in the post-impact ocean. Given the inability of the Deccan Traps warming to generate HEATT-driven anoxia, this dysoxic fauna might reflect the short-lived impact-generated warming followed by sinking of warm, oxygenpoor brines. Recent work, however, suggests that the Deccan Traps may not have erupted until about the time of the extinction (Chenet et al., 2008). That paleomagnetic work confines the eruptions to the upper part of the C29r magnetic chron and the overlying basal portion of the C29n chron. If this is so, the Deccan Traps could not have begun to initiate a HEATT episode until virtually the same time as the impact and extinction. Chenet et al. (2008) suggest that the Deccan Traps eruptions may have predated the impact slightly. Either way, this would represent an extremely unlikely and unique coincidence. Recent results from Robinson et al. (2009) suggest that the main (2nd) phase of the Deccan Traps eruptions predated the extinction horizon by about 200,000 to 300,000 years.Whatever the Deccan Trap eruptive timing turns out to be, this significant LIP triggered only a weak HEATT episode. This difficulty may well reflect the preceding long-term regression and possible presence of small polar ice caps in a cool Greenhouse climate that kept thermohaline circulation in a weak thermal mode. This precondition would have to be overcome before a HEATT episode could get underway.
We suggest that the impact instantaneously amplified a weak HEATT episode that was already in progress. The combined effect of CO2-based greenhouse warming by volcanism and impact generated a short-term CO2-driven thermal pulse that rapidly decayed. The sinking warm brines characteristic of other HEATTs did not develop beyond the ability to generate only minor dysoxia and no deep-ocean warming. Given that this particular HEATT was a weak one, it alone might not have been as devastating to life as many of the other ones that were accompanied by anoxia. The occurrence of a large impact during a weak HEATT episode may well have been a unique event in Phanerozoic history given that HEATT episodes represent less than 4% of the Phanerozoic record and that other large impacts did not cause major extinction.

sections.heading: 7.1. Cambrian HEATT
sections.text:
Multiple Cambrian HEATT episodes are suggested by Fig. 1 and other factors. The Botomian episodes are best supported by the factors in Table 1. HEATT conditionsmay have been operating just prior to the Cambrian (Fig. 1; Table 1) in association with the demise of the Ediacaran Fauna. The upper Cambrian SPICE (Steptoean Positive Carbon Isotope Excursion) has several attributes of a HEATT episode
such as low 87Sr/86Sr (LIP-driven?) and intensified carbon burial (Saltzman et al., 1995; Saltzman et al., 2000a). However, despite an early suggestion of a transgression (Saltzman et al., 1995), the prevailing view now favors a HEATT-incompatible regression at this horizon instead (Saltzman et al., 2004). Also, the SPICE event is marked by a strongly positive ∂13C excursion (Saltzman et al., 1995; Saltzman et al., 2000a; Saltzman et al., 2004). Haq and Schutter (2008) noted a high-frequency (Milankovitch) sea-level oscillation interval bracketing the SPICE excursion that adds further complication. Although the positive ∂13C shift does not disqualify the SPICE as a HEATT episode, it does require explanation. The fundamental Mesozoic shift in marine archaea and its implications for positive ∂13C shifts (Kuypers et al., 2001) cannot be used for Paleozoic HEATT episodes. The possibility of sustaining near-HEATT conditions that favor intense productivity of green algae (Fig. 5) could explain the positive carbon isotopic shift, but if regression rather than transgression characterizes the SPICE interval, the case for a HEATT event remains weak. The Cambro-Ordovician boundary shows some features consistent with a HEATT episode (Fig. 1), but, like the late Precambrian and SPICE possibilities, we have not yet delved deeply into this horizon.
The stratigraphically distinct, but poorly radiometrically dated midBotomian displays many earmarks of a sharply focused HEATT episode (Fig. 1). This HEATT interval is a fairly straightforward fit to the model for a rapid shift from Greenhouse to Hothouse conditions. The cause of the extinction has been linked to anoxia at this time (Zhuravlev and Wood, 1996). Anoxia is expected for aHothouse climate (Fig. 1; Table 1). Isotopic anomalies that characterize this interval include a sharply negative pre-SPICE ∂13C spike (Brasier et al., 1994; Saltzman et al., 2000a) and a strongly positive shift in ∂34S (Hough et al., 2006). Although direct evidence for euxinia has yet to emerge, the strong sulfur isotopic shift suggests that euxinic conditions probably existed. The north Australian flood basalts of the Kalkarindji LIP (Glass and Phillips, 2006)were the likely trigger of this HEATT episode, but age datingmust be refined for acceptance of a Kalkarindji trigger for the mid-Botomian HEATT episode. The extensive anoxia has been linked by Zhuravlev and Wood (1996) with a transgression (Rowland and Gangloff, 1988) that probably marked the HEATT climax.
This selective Botomian extinction has been called the Sinsk event by Zhuravlev and Wood (1996). The “Tommotian fauna” was sharply curtailed, and both trilobites and archaeocyathans were reduced to a lesser extent. Echinoderms and lingulid brachiopods, by contrast, passed through this event relatively unscathed. Fleshy chlorophytic green algae were abundant on both the Siberian and Yangtze platforms (Zhuravlev and Wood, 1996).
Although available data on the Botomian are consistent with the HEATT model, this interval is not without its complications. Age relationships are somewhat loosely constrained. Recently obtained ages on the Kalkarindji basalts of 508 Ma and 505 Ma appear too young for LIP triggering of a HEATT at the 510 Ma horizon at which the sulfur isotope anomaly and extinction occur. Other dates of 510 Ma for the Antrim province of the Kalkarindji LIP (e.g. Bultitude, 1976) favor a closer match. There is enough general agreement in timing to hope for resolution of the age issues asmore age date relationships are collected. A minor paradox has to do with archaeocyathans. Although archaeocyathans suffered minor extinctions during the Botomian Sinsk event, they underwent amuchmore substantial extinction during the subsequent Hawke Bay event in the Toyonian (Rowland and Shapiro, 2002). The Hawke Bay event is closely associated with a regression (Hallam andWignall, 1997), and it is bracketed by a series of high-frequency sea-level oscillations at Milankovitch scale (Haq and Schutter, 2008). Loss of ecosystem space may have been a key factor in the sharp reduction in archaeocyathan diversity at this extinction horizon. As noted earlier, it is our expectation that coral reefs can potentially serve as a “coal-mine canary” as HEATT episodes develop. The sponge-like archaeocyathans (Rowland, 2001) did not conform to
that expectation. That they suffered only minimally during the HEATT episode suggests thatmanyof the ill effects generatedduring theHEATT episodemay have been stresses towhich theywere readily adaptable. A third inconsistency with regard to the Botomian is that the HEATT episodehas been suggested tohave beenphosphate rich (Zhuravlev and Wood, 1996). Younger HEATT episodes are consistent with model predictions in that they tend to be associatedwithminima or even gaps in phosphorite deposition such as the conspicuous one in the early Triassic (Trappe, 1998). If iron-limitation and increased importance of ammonium as leading fertilizers of marine productivity developed, as seems common onmost HEATT episodes, phosphorus should have been present in excess relative to normal nutrient requirements. The stratigraphy on the Siberian Platform suggests that although the Botomian sections there are generally phosphate rich, the phosphatic horizons noted by Shergold and Brasier (1986) occur at horizons two zones above and three zones below the negative ∂13C excursion (Brasier et al., 1994) that marks the HEATT. So, even in the P-rich Cambrian ocean, there may have been phosphorite gaps at HEATT horizons. We predict this relationship to hold in other phosphate-rich Cambrian sections that preserve the Sinsk event and at the other potential Cambrian HEATTs should they turn out to be Hothouses.

sections.heading: 7.2. Ordovician and Devonian glacial interruptions
sections.text:
The obvious concern with the suggestion of HEATT episodes in both the late Ordovician and late Devonian is the brief glaciations at each interval. We have already suggested that LIPs will be most effective in stimulating HEATT episodes when competing factors are minimized. For example, themajor glaciations of the Cenozoic and the Carboniferous–early Permian are Icehouses that were probably stimulated and sustained by silicate weathering and carbon burial during significant continental-collisions such as that of India and Asia in the Cenozoic and the collision of Gondwanaland and Laurasia in the Carboniferous.We speculate that the relativelyminor orogenies of the Devonian and late Ordovician (e.g. Murphy et al., 2009) were not potent enough to stimulate glaciations. Rather than causing glaciations such as has been proposed for the Taconic orogeny (Kump et al., 1999) and the Antler orogeny (Saltzman et al., 2000b), the silicate weathering of these small mountain belts may merely have exerted a cooling influence. If small orogenic events can generate glaciation, there should be more glaciations in the geologic record.
Innovations in terrestrial vegetation can potentially stimulate glaciation. Algeo and Scheckler (1998) invoked plant-driven glacial stimulation in the late Devonian. The increase in depth of rooting as trees originated and radiated in the Givetian would have deepened the zone of silicate weathering (Algeo and Scheckler, 1998). Additionally, the Famennian rise and expansion of seeds would allow plant life to reproduce in areas other than the wet, lowland settings required by seedless plants into upland areas where protective seed coatings allowed reproductive materials to persist in drier regions until moisture became available (Algeo and Scheckler, 1998). This increase in vegetated land area coupledwith the increased depth of weathering in soils may well have been the key to stimulating the late Devonian glaciation. Carbon burial in marine black shales and in limited late Devonian coals would also have been important (Algeo and Scheckler, 1998). We suggest that these plant innovations were sufficient to stifle HEATT-favoring conditions because of the cooling and the expected oxygenation of the oceans with the strengthening of the thermal mode of deep-ocean circulation (Fig. 2).
We speculate that the increase in plant biomass would have further contributed to cooling by fertilizing the oceans with nitrate and phosphate, stimulating productivity and carbon burial (Fig. 7). Plants would draw these nutrients from soils, but then those nutrients would be released during plant decay. Some of those nutrients would be recycled into new plant life, but some would escape to the oceans
via rivers. Additionally, plant material carried by rivers would deliver nutrients to the oceans (e.g. Berner and Rao, 1994).
A speculative case for vegetation-stimulated glaciation can also be made for the late Ordovician. It is increasingly apparent that primitive vegetation such as liverworts and/or fungi had begun to populate late Ordovician terrestrial landscapes (Gensel, 2008). The spread of such vegetation across the landscapewould have increased levels of silicate weathering, though not to the degree achieved by trees and seed plants in the late Devonian. Furthermore, terrestrial carbon burial in coal was nonexistent in the late Ordovician. Some carbonwould likely be stored in newly developing soils, but probably most important would be ocean fertilization from runoff laden with nutrients extracted from rock and primitive soils by these liverworts and/or fungi (Fig. 7).
Vegetation-driven glacial pulses would probably develop rapidly, and would be likely to be short lived. We speculate that the initiation of such a glaciation would be due to a new style of carbon burial that would be substantial enough to cool the planet until carbon consumers adapted or evolved to recycle much of that carbon.

sections.heading: 7.3. Ordovician HEATT
sections.text:
The prescient suggestion by Railsback et al. (1990) that the Caradocian ocean was characterized by evaporation-driven warm waters that sank at low-to-mid latitudes and flowed poleward at depth is characteristic of a HEATT episode. The Caradocian is well known as a warm interval marked by a significant transgression in the middle (Barnes et al., 1996) and several other smaller transgressive events (Qing et al., 1998; Haq and Schutter, 2008). However, the late Ordovician glaciation interrupts that warmth (Brenchley et al., 1994; Marshall et al., 1997), and the first pulse of the two-phase extinction coincides with onset of this brief Icehouse climate (Sheehan, 2001). The second pulse of the extinction takes place during the warming at the end of the glaciation (Sheehan, 2001). Although it seems logical to expect that this warmingmay simply have been post-glacial warming, it is also worth considering that the glaciation is a brief interruption of a developing HEATT episode that peaked after the ice melted.
The lack of a known late Ordovician LIP weakens the case for a HEATT episode. However, the well-known Caradocian volcanism (e.g. Huff et al., 1992; Barnes et al., 1996) coupled with the sharp drop in 87Sr/86Sr throughout the Caradocian (Qing et al., 1998) is consistent with themajor volcanism needed to generate a late Ordovician HEATT episode having been an oceanic LIP. The sharp pulse in ophiolite abundance in the late Ordovician (Vaughan and Scarrow, 2003) is also consistent with the suggestion of a significant oceanic LIP (Dilek and Ernst, 2008).
Model results based on a new carbon-associated sulfur (CAS)based ∂34S curve for the Phanerozoic show a pattern of bacterial sulfate reduction that increases in a series of pulses through the late Ordovician (Kampschulte and Strauss, 2004). The Kampschulte and Strauss (2004) curve appears to be plotted on a less-than-current time scale, and some short-term events are smeared. Nevertheless, the patterns are intriguing. Bacterial sulfate reduction peaked in the late Caradoc, andwas sharply curtailedwhen the glaciation began.We speculate that these bacterial sulfate reduction pulses correspond to the transgressive events that mark the late Ordovician (e.g. Qing et al., 1998; Haq and Schutter, 2008). Such transgressive pulses would have spread anoxic and/or euxinic waters. The last such pre-glacial pulse was probably the Boda global warming event that is marked by transgressive graptolitic black shale (Fortey and Cocks, 2005). Pyrite framboids and/or isorenieratene characterize the post-glacial black shales of the basal Silurian of Jordan (Armstrong et al., 2009). Although extinction does not appear to have been linkedwith the preglacial transgressive pulses, we interpret the post-glacial transgression as the culmination of the HEATT episode. The immediacy of the appearance of post-glacial euxina (Armstrong et al., 2009) supports
the idea of rapid onset of HEATT conditions. The HEATT component of thermal expansion would be masked by the volume of melted ice. We suggest that rapid development of Hothouse conditions is a more likely driver of extinction than transgression driven simply by glacial melting. A melt-only-driven transgression would expand shelf ecosystem space and be more likely affiliated with a radiation than with extinction, particularly in the tropics. Transgression accompanied by euxinia in a HEATT event is likely to have been deadly to life.
The selectivity of the late Ordovician two-phase extinction shows aspects that are consistent with an interrupted HEATT episode. However, in a warmworld such as the pre-glacial late Ordovician, it is not surprising that the abrupt onset of a short enigmatic glaciation caused the first wave of late Ordovician extinctions. Graptolites, trilobites, brachiopods, bryozoans, and echinoderms, for example, suffered from either cold and/or regression-induced loss of habitat (see Hallam and Wignall, 1997).
Although the rugose corals suffered reductions at both the onset and termination of the glaciation, the tabulate coral-stromatoporoid reefs were only minimally affected as the glaciation got underway. However, this tabulate-stromatoporoid ecosystem was decimated during the warmup, and a pronounced gap followed that lasted about halfway through the Llandoverian (Hallam and Wignall, 1997; Berry et al., 2002; Veron, 2008). The sponge-affinities of the stromatoporoids mean that these taxa may not have been directly affected by the warming, but the demise of the probably-more-sensitive corals led to stromatoporoid extinction because of their close ecosystem ties with the tabulates. The delayed recovery of the tabulates may well have been what allowed the rugosans to replace tabulates as the dominant corals following the end of the Ordovician.
If the warmup were a mere recovery from glaciation, it would be expected that tropical tabulates might adapt as readily to the end of glaciation as they did to its beginning. However, that they survived the cooling and were then devastated during the warming suggests that warming and related factors were the consummate causes of their demise. Tabulates in the tropics would be expected to survive glaciation given theminimal cooling there. Although habitat loss from sea-level fall must have occurred, these effects appear minor with respect to the overall tabulate survival.
Acritarchs underwent extinctions during the onset of glaciation (Hallam and Wignall, 1997). A likely cause for this diversity drop is because of a surge in nitrate production as glacially oxygenated oceans favored oxidized nitrogen (nitrate), to which these microbes were not well adapted. During HEATT episodes, primitive plankton such as green algae (e.g. prasinophytes) thrive. The same goes for the acritarchs. Green algae are not very productive when nitrate is their nutrient source (Litchman, 2007). The same probably goes for the acritarchs. We predict that a late Ordovician acritarch gap is the likely result of a spike in oceanic nitrate abundance during the glaciationdriven ocean ventilation. Recent ∂15N results (LaPorte et al., 2009) support this prediction (Table 1; Fig. 6). Most ∂15N values in the Nevada sections studied by LaPorte et al. (2009) are below 2‰. Their Vinni Creek section is marked by a positive ∂15N spike that is consistent with the onset of glaciation.

sections.heading: 7.4. Devonian HEATT
sections.text:
The mid–late Devonian is marked by multiple transgressive– regressive pulses (Johnson et al., 1985; Sandberg et al., 2002).Warming
(Thompson and Newton, 1988; Joachimski et al., 2009), Famennian glaciation (Caputo and Crowell, 1985), widespread anoxia (Buggisch, 1991; Joachimski and Buggisch, 1993; Murphy et al., 2000), positive ∂13C excursions (Joachimski et al., 2002), and a negative ∂15N at the Frasnian–Fammenian boundary (Levman and von Bitter, 2002) also characterize this complex interval. The transgressions have been linked with anoxia (e.g. Bond andWignall, 2005; Bond andWignall, 2008). The mid–late Devonian extinction pulses (see McGhee, 1996 review) have been attributed to a range of causes including anoxia (Bond et al., 2004; Bond and Wignall, 2005; Bond and Wignall, 2008), warming (Thompson and Newton, 1988; Hillbun et al., 2008) and cooling in the Famennian (Copper, 1986; Joachimski and Buggisch, 2002).
We interpret the series of transgressions that Johnson et al. (1985) identified through the middle and late Devonian as the result of conditions that reflect nascent HEATT conditions and finally become a HEATT episode at the Frasnian–Famennian boundary. The Frasnian– Famennian boundary has recently been reinterpreted as coincident with a widespread anoxic transgressive pulse (Bond and Wignall, 2008), and negative ∂13C excursion mark this horizon in Iran, south China, and the Urals (Gharaie et al., 2007).
Direct evidence for a LIP trigger for late Devonian HEATT activity is tenuous. Famennian age dates on the East European Craton LIP (Fig. 1) indicate that this volcanism was too little and too late to stimulate thermal-expansion-driven transgressive pulses. However, the 365 Ma LIP age dates may be recording only late-stage activity such as feeder dikes. Additionally, the sharp and strongly negative 87Sr/86Sr excursion (van Geldern et al., 2006; John, et al., 2008) is consistent with strong basaltic volcanism through the Givetian and Frasnian.
Positive ∂13C anomalies are common in the late Devonian (e.g. Joachimski and Buggisch, 2002). Like the Cenomanian–Turonian and earlier Cretaceous positive ∂13C anomalies, the late Devonian positive excursions are consistent with high oceanic productivity. The negative excursion in ∂15N at the Frasnian/Famennian boundary black shale in western Canada as well as at the next two succeeding Famennian black shales (Levman and Von Bitter, 2002) is expected under HEATT conditions.
Goddéris and Joachimski (2004) modeled late Devonian positive ∂13C shifts. To account for a +3‰ excursion, they suggested that weathering of carbonates could account for +0.7‰, and that another +1.0‰ could be generated by the rise of arborescence that began in the Givetian (Algeo and Scheckler, 1998). The additional phosphorus input to the oceans that Goddéris and Joachimski (2004) call upon to stimulate enough carbon burial tomake up the remaining+1.3‰ is not consistent with the HEATT model. Their model requires a 40% increase in delivery of continental phosphorus to the oceans to generate the needed carbon burial.
Murphy et al. (2000) looked to deeper waters for nutrient supplies to stimulate oceanic productivity. They suggested that seasonal overturn could bring up regenerated N and P to sustain high productivity during deposition of late Devonian black shales. The C: N:P ratios reported by Murphy et al. (2000) suggest that nitrogen abundance jumped substantially in each black shale. That productivity and nitrogen appear to be rising in lock step is consistent with our prediction and that of Saltzman (2005) that phosphorus is not limiting during Devonian warmth.
We suggest alternative solutions to the positive ∂13C excursions and underlying high productivity in the black shales. First, the HEATT model predicts that because phosphorus is not the limiting nutrient, phosphorus will be in excess relative to Icehouses (see Saltzman, 2005) when it is limiting. Iron will be the limiting nutrient in oceans during HEATT episodes because the reduced winds will not deliver sufficient iron dust to most oceanic areas to feed the diazotrophic bacteria that produce ammonium. Delivery of nutrients from beneath the photic zone by major cyclonic storm activity presents an alternative to the seasonal overturn events proposed by Murphy et al. (2000). As outlined in the model section earlier in this paper, these
storms will reach far deeper than modern cyclonic storms. Storms might approach a wave-base depth of 400 m based on assumptions of deep-water temperatures N20 °C (Korty et al., 2008). With reduced planetary windbelt velocities leading to reductions in coastal upwelling, these storms may well have been the dominant supplier of nutrients from deep water. Ammonium and reduced iron would be delivered from deeper waters. This mechanism would be most effective just before and just after the HEATT peak (Fig. 5). During the deadly HEATT climax, poisonous euxinic waters would be mined by the large cyclones.
Devonian planktonic productivity may have benefitted from one other factor. Schwark and Empt (2006) noted a brief late Devonian change from relatively primitive C29-sterane producing algae to modern-like C28-sterane producing algae. After the Devonian, that short-lived pulse reverted to more primitive steranes (C29) until the Triassic when advanced levels return during the dinoflagellate radiation. The upward shift in C28/C29 ratio continued later with the rise of other plankton with red-algal ancestry such as coccoliths, silicoflagellates, and diatoms (Schwark and Empt, 2006). We suggest that the temporary shift to more evolutionary advanced biomarker values may reflect superior productivity, probably by prasinophytes, which tend to be enriched in C28 steroid biomarkers. Pronounced spikes in C28/C29 ratio mark four key anoxic horizons (Upper Kacak; both Kellwasser horizons; Hangenberg) in the mid–late Devonian (Schwark and Empt, 2006), supporting this contention. Ammonium was probably the dominant nutrient under the conditions of the HEATT model, and this is supported by the negative ∂15N spike (Fig. 6). Prasinophytes are particularly effective at using ammonium, as discussed earlier (and see Litchman, 2007). They were able to flourish most effectively under these conditions, probably at the expense of the acritarchs. The acritarchs probably also “preferred” ammonium, but for some reason not yet known, the prasinophytes were able to succeed most effectively. The acritarchs declined markedly after the Devonian (Downie, 1984; Strother, 1996).
Given a number of similarities between the Ordovician and Devonian HEATT intervals, it is worth noting that the sterane biomarkers show a sharp increase in C28/C29 ratio at the upper extinction horizon in the late Hirnantian (Schwark and Empt, 2006). This coincides with the warming, transgression, and tabulate coral extinction discussed earlier that we interpret as a rapid return to the Hothouse that had been briefly interrupted by glaciation.
Copper (2002) reported Devonian coral extinctions that preceded the Frasnian–Famennian (F/F) extinction. He noted the loss of eight tabulate families and twelve rugose families by the end of the Givetian, whereas only one tabulate family and six rugose families went extinct at the F/F boundary. The extinction pulses in the stepwise departure of the coral-based ecosystem do not correlate with anoxic late Devonian episodes (Copper, 2002). Although it is tempting to suggest that these sensitive taxa may have succumbed to intense warmth and/or hypercapnia and/or ocean acidification as HEATT conditions were developing, the Devonian coral extinctions coincide with regression (Copper, 2002; Gharaie et al., 2007).

sections.heading: 7.5. The Guadalupian: an enigmatic HEATT?
sections.text:
The end-Guadalupian extinction tempts consideration as a HEATT event because it is associated with the Emeishan LIP (Fig. 1). It has been considered as the first pulse in a 2-phase extinction in the Permian that was followed by the end-Permian extinction (Stanley and Yang 1994). This extinction affected biotas in both terrestrial and marine settings (Stanley and Yang 1994; Retallack et al., 2006; Groves et al., 2007; Lai et al., 2008). However, the marine extinction in Sichuan, China is selective in that it mainly affected fusilinaceans and perhaps calcareous algae. Hallam andWignall (1997) synthesized the diversity contractions at the end of the Maokouan (= end of middle Permian = end Guadalupian). They noted abrupt extinctions among
ammonoids, rugose corals, complex foraminiferans, and articulate brachiopods. They also showed diversity declines in bryozoans and crinioids that continued further into the overlying Wujiapingian. Retallack et al. (2006) called attention to a marine transgression in southeastern Australia and Arctic Canada. They also recognized a −4‰ excursion in ∂13C, suggesting methane release as the driver of excursion, and calling for intense global warming as a result of that greenhouse gas emission that was emitted when the Emeishan LIP intruded coal measures. The Emeishan is a small LIP (Fig. 1), and it is not entirely certain that it precedes the extinction. However, recent work by Ganino and Arndt (2009) shows that considerable degassing of carbonate and sulfate strata resulted from contact with the relatively small Emeishan LIP. Wignall et al. (2009a) showed that extinctions of fusulinid foraminifers and calcareous algae coincided with the Emeishan LIP eruptions, but preceded the negative ∂13C excursion. Wignall et al. (2009b) pointed out that transgression and the spread of dysoxic waters also followed the foraminiferan extinction. This supports our earlier suggestion that sensitive organisms like foraminiferans may suffer extinction prior to HEATT climax. Furthermore, seed ferns record stomatal evidence of high atmospheric CO2 (Retallack, 2002), consistent with global warmth. Detrimental to HEATT considerations, however, are the lack of widespread anoxia in shallow-marine facies and the prevailing view that sea level fell at the end of the Guadalupian (e.g. Haq and Schutter, 2008; Lai et al., 2008). Our evaluation of the Guadalupian as a possible HEATT event is inconclusive and, in many respects, comparable to the similarly enigmatic Upper Cambrian SPICE event. Finally, a reassessment of the late Permian paleontological data base (Clapham et al., 2009) suggests that a prolonged gradual decline in diversity characterized the Permian from the Wordian up to the end-Permian extinction event, and that there was no distinct mass extinction event in the Guadalupian.

sections.heading: 8.1. Paleocene/Eocene Thermal Maximum (PETM)
sections.text:
The PETM was a severe, but short-lived global warming event marked by only minimal extinctions (Fig. 1). The PETM was first recognized on the basis of the formation of warm, deep water and the possible link between that deep-water warming and the extinction of deep-water foraminifera (Kennett and Stott, 1991). The intense, rapid rise in global average temperature of 5 °C in less than 10,000 years (Zachos et al., 2008) illustrates just how rapidly a HEATT episode can be initiated. The increase in tropical sea surface temperatures of 5 °C in the tropics and 6 °C in the Arctic (see Storey et al., 2007) is consistent with those modeled for the much longer lasting terminal Permian HEATT (Kidder and Worsley, 2004). The doubling of Arctic humidity in the Eocene (Jahren and Sternberg, 2003) is also comparable with end-Permian conditions (Kidder and Worsley, 2004), and increased poleward latent heat transport for the PETM (Ludvigson et al., 2008) is also consistent with HEATT predictions. The ocean acidification (Zachos et al., 2005) and the linkage of sinking, warm, dysoxic waters to the deep ocean to extinction of 30–50% of the benthic Paleocene foram species (Thomas, 2007) are consistent with the HEATT model, although anoxia and euxinia appear not to have fully developed during the PETM. The rapid reversal in deep-ocean circulation and its linkage to increased warming of deep-sea waters (Bice and Marotzke, 2002; Nunes and Norris, 2006) attests to the rapidity of involvement in thermohaline circulation in rapid climate changes, although the style of circulation they model differs from that proposed herein.
The increasing likelihood that the release of ocean methane may not be the primary driver of warming at the PETM supports inclusion of the PETM within the family of HEATT episodes. Recent work suggests that althoughmethanemaywell have produced the negative
∂13C spike, there was not enough sea-floor dissolution of calcium carbonate to compensate for the 2000 Gt of methane commonly invoked for explaining the magnitude of the ∂13C spike (Panchuk et al., 2008). Furthermore, there does not seem to have been enough methane to cause the deep-seawarming. Tripati and Elderfield (2005) suggest that the 2000 Gt could have generated only about 1 °C in deep sea warming as opposed to the 4°–5 °C increase that has been recognized. In addition, the ∂13C spike appears to have come some 3000 years after the main LIP heating (Sluijs et al., 2007). Zachos (2008) recently proposed a new methane emission scenario to better explain these new developments. He called for two pulses of methane emission, with the first being 3000 Gt and the second 1400 Gt. If the larger of the two suggested methane pulses came first though, a negative ∂13C spike would be expected to have occurred in association with that earlier negative spike. If the initial warming was not methane driven, the single, later negative carbon isotopic spikemakes more sense. The 3000-year delay is enough time for sinking warm brines to make one pass through the deep ocean, but that brief window was too short for such brines to have heated the deep ocean. Nevertheless, methane remains the most likely explanation for the negative ∂13C spike at the PETM.
Recent results suggest a chronology of steps for the PETM that are consistent with the HEATT model. These include: 1) LIP injection of greenhouse gases into the atmosphere as the North Atlantic Volcanic Province (NAVP) became active (Fig. 1). Svensen et al. (2004) and Storey et al. (2007) both suggested that the NAVP intruded through methane-rich ocean sediments, perhaps increasing the potency of this LIP relative to older examples that may have mainly emitted only carbon dioxide. This explains the likely source of the first methane pulse called for by Zachos (2008), but does not explain why there is only one negative ∂13C spike. 2) The mid-latitude heating with temperature increases of up to 8 °C in shallow water (Zachos et al., 2006) would be a next step predicted by the HEATT model (Figs. 2, 3), but it is not clear if this heating followed the LIP. 3) The warm, deepwater formation was documented long ago as mentioned above (Kennett and Stott, 1991) as was 4) the extinction of deep-water forams (Kennett and Stott, 1991). The timing of 5) the transgression is predicted herein to have coincided with the formation of deep warm water.
The transgression (Speijer and Wagner, 2002) is not yet established as a global event. It is present at southern Tethyan margin sections in Egypt and Israel as well as on the northern Tethyanmargin and New Jersey, USA. Speijer and Wagner (2002) suggest that this transgression may have been a eustatic event. They also note its association with dysoxia and, in places, anoxia. Speijer and Wagner (2002) suggest that the transgression was on the order of 20 m. They propose that the temperature changeswere responsible for 8 mworth of that transgression by thermal expansion of ocean water. The absence of radiolaria, diatoms, and dinoflagellates at this horizon prompted Speijer andWagner (2002) to suggest decreased upwelling strength. Such a decrease is consistent with the predicted weakening of wind, lessened iron dust input to oceans and increased iron limitation.
Anoxia does not seem to have developed as fully at the PETM as in other HEATT episodes (Table 1). Anoxia has not been reported in deep waters at the PETM (Zachos et al., 2008). Accordingly, we would not expect any euxinia and so would not expect major extinctions either. Deep-water forams do appear to have suffered from oxygen deficiency though (Tripati and Elderfield, 2005). We are aware of no reports of anomalous ∂34S or ∂15N. Neither do we know of the presence of sterane biomarkers or prasinophyte-rich horizons.
The PETM was a more rapid and less devastating HEATT episode than the others proposed herein. Anoxia did not develop as fully, and extinction was not nearly as drastic as at other HEATT horizons, possibly due to the very short duration of the overall episode, which was probably 170,000 years or less (Zachos et al., 2008) and lack of
euxinia. The short duration of the HEATT episode could be due to short-lived LIP activity or perhaps weak LIP activity that was intensified by the NAVP intruding through methane-rich sediments, leading to a brief, but methane-amplified HEATT episode. The strong possibility that many other PETM-like events exist in the Paleozoic geologic record will be challenging to recognize without the benefit of the deep-sea record of the Mesozoic and Cenozoic.

sections.heading: 9. Conclusions
sections.text:
The HEATT model offers a systemic explanation of the feedbacks that result from the volcanic outpourings associated with major Large Igneous Provinces (LIPs). HEATT episodes are much more likely, and have only been recognized, when LIPs erupt amid the precondition of a Greenhouse climate when silicate weathering is minimal. The Icehouse climate precondition of vigorous, thermal-mode ocean circulation (Zhang et al., 2001) retards HEATT episode development. Active continental collisional orogenies compete with LIPs by favoring glaciation or at least thermal-mode circulation. Under Greenhouse preconditions, emission of greenhouse gases from these LIPs only begins planetary warming. That warming melts polar ice (if present), and latitudinal expansion of warmth and dryness leads to brine formation in evaporative basins connected to the world ocean. These sinking brines deliver heat and sulfate to deep waters. The sinking, warm, oxygen-poor brine (e.g. Brass et al., 1982) becomes the dominant driver of haline-mode ocean circulation (Zhang et al., 2001). This style of circulation is sustainable only as long as the LIP CO2 production remains voluminous. Expansion of anoxia at depth is a conspicuous result of oceans in which minimal oxygen is delivered to the deep sea. Warm brines deliver heat to high latitudes. That warm water rises until obstructed by a strong halocline that developed as high-latitude climates became warm and wet enough to sustain forests (e.g. Taylor and Ryberg, 2007).
Numerous positive feedbacks intensify the conditions that lead to and characterize the Hothouse planetary climate state. Reduced poleequator thermal gradients sharply lower planetarywindbelt velocities progressing from Icehouse to Greenhouse to Hothouse planetary states. Wind shear drops as a function of the square of velocity, and wind erosive power falls as the cube of wind velocity. Surface ocean currents weaken as wind strength fades, so delivery of heat to high latitudes by those currents and winds diminishes. The atmosphere's role in poleward heat transport will increase in two ways. First, latent heat transport will increase with increased evaporation in warmer tropics. The increased moisture in polar regions will result in moist climates, and polar clouds will trap heat at those latitudes, minimizing its escape to space. Second, cyclonic storms will play an increasingly important heat-transport role in Greenhouse and Hothouse climates (Kidder and Worsley, 2004; Korty et al., 2008). Weakened winds and warming oceans allow tropical cyclonic storms to form more readily. In Hothouses, cyclones are larger, more frequent, and longer lasting than in Icehouses or Greenhouses. Because deep waters will have warmed in the Hothouse, such cyclones no longer draw up cool water to limit tropical warming as they do today. Instead, they tap warm water so as to become even stronger and reach even deeper. Cyclonic storms escape the tropics in Hothouse climates. At high latitudes, intense cyclonic storms will mine heat from rising warm waters beneath the halocline, further weakening pole-equator thermal gradients and intensifying warming. Expansion of warm waters to high latitudes, helped in part by the storms themselves and also by geothermal heating will enable cyclones to travel to high latitudes. These slow-moving heat engines will be stopped only where they lose moisture by drifting over large landmasses.
With the loss of wind-driven upwelling, the cyclonic storms become the chief mechanism for bringing nutrients from deep to shallow waters. The exponentially diminished erosive power of the wind will deliver minimal dust to the oceans, resulting in severe iron
limitation and hence, nitrogen limitation. During the initial onset of a Hothouse, bioavailable nitrogen will occur as reduced forms such as ammonium. The minimal nutrient recycling in the Hothouse requires intensive nitrogen fixation where levels of iron and molybdenumwill permit it. The dominance of usable nutrients by freshly fixed nitrogen will drive down ∂15N values. With iron, molybdenum, and nitrogen serving as the chief limitation on nutrients, phosphorus will be in excess, leading to gaps in phosphate deposition or even primary precipitation. Primary producers will adjust to these shifts in nutrient cycling with profound results. “Red” algal forms such as dinoflagellates, diatoms, and coccoliths will have difficulty because the nitrate that normally gives them an advantage over more primitive “green” algal plankton will diminish. The “green” algal plankton, which are not well adapted to using nitrate, will thrive on reduced nitrogen species such as ammonium that they are more efficient at using than their “red” algal cousins. Preliminary results in sterane biomarker analysis confirm this conclusion.
As the oceanwarms, thermal expansionwill drive a transgression of about 10–30 m, depending on the conditions in a given HEATT episode. If methane hydrates are released from sea-floor sediments by the warming they will further intensify heating and will contribute to a negative ∂13C anomaly. At some HEATTs, the negative anomaly is offset enough by other factors to generate a positive ∂13C excursion. We suggest that methane may be a less important factor than is often suggested in the literature. Most or all of the warming can be achieved without the methane because the CO2 sets up the ocean–atmosphere feedbacks discussed above that are probably greater than the methane effect. The negative ∂13C anomalies commonly attributed to methane can be explained by productivity loss (Broecker and Peacock, 1999) and by shifts to light carbon isotopes as luxury feeding is driven by increasing carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. For each doubling of atmospheric CO2, ∂13C can drop by 1‰ (e.g. Galimov (1985)). The several doublings suggested by Kidder and Worsley (2004) can easily account for the negative ∂13C spike at the Permo-Triassic boundary. The intensification of Hothouse conditions such as heat, anoxia, euxinia, shifts in nutrient cycling, ocean acidification, and hypercapnia probably caused mass extinction at least ten times during the Phanerozoic.
Fig. 1 illustrates 21 Phanerozoic extinction horizons. The late Edicaran extinction is not shown on that figure, and only one extinction appears where two exist in the late Ordovician. Of those 23 extinctions, 4 are attributable to regression/cooling, and 3 others are problematic. We interpret the remaining 16 as HEATT episodes (Fig. 1; Table 1). We recognize well-defined HEATT episodes during the Cenomanian– Turonian, Toarcian, end-Triassic, end-Permian, and Cambrian (Botomian). Frequent and less well-studied HEATTs mark the early Cretaceous during Aptian, Albian, and Valanginian. The late Ordovician and late Devonian were pulsed HEATT episodes that were briefly interrupted by glaciation. The Paleocene–Eocene Thermal Maximum was a HEATT episode that developed quickly, and then aborted before reaching the deadly climax recognized at other HEATTs. The brevity and unsustainability of the PETM may reflect a short-lived trigger such as intrusion of the long-lived North Atlantic Volcanic Province into methane-rich sediments. Each HEATT episode has unique aspects depending on factors such as magnitude of LIP and other competing factors that may generate negative feedback such as orogenic activity and new innovations in plant life that stimulate increases in silicate weathering. The late Ediacaran, Cambro-Ordovician, and Pragian are potential HEATT episodes that have not been investigated as thoroughly as those discussed above.
The end-CretaceousHEATT is quiteweak, andwe attribute this to the precondition of a strengthening thermalmode of deep-ocean circulation as middle to late Cretaceous climates cooled and sea level generally fell. The weak HEATT effects instigated by the Deccan Traps were greatly amplified by the Chicxulub impact in the Yucatan carbonates. Vaporization of carbonates released considerable CO2 to the atmosphere, creating a short-lived HEATT episode. Recentmagnetostratigraphic ages
shorten and focus the powerful Deccan eruptions to a brief interval quite close to the K–Pg boundary (Chenet et al., 2008). The anoxia typical of most HEATTs did not develop to any great extent at the end of the Cretaceous. The newly shortened duration of the Deccan Traps trigger maybepart of the reasonwhytheHEATTdidnotdevelopas fully as older ones.
The progressive development of a HEATT event should yield a stepwise record of detrimental biotic effects leading up to the extinction climax. During the initial stages of the HEATT episode, the rising atmospheric CO2, warming, and mid-latitude drying should affect terrestrial life, perhaps leading to precursor extinctions on land. Sensitive shallow-marine organisms will be stressed to extinction by heat, ocean acidification, and hypercapnia. Next, as sinking of warm brines intensifies, deep-water benthic species will suffer fromwarming and/or stress from low-oxygen levels. As anoxia expands and euxinia develops, outer-shelf biotasmaybe stressed before inner shelf-dwellers. Outer-shelf extinctionsmay precede inner shelf ones and/or outer-shelf organisms may move into shallower waters until the transgression brings about the peak in extinction.
Of the Icehouse, Greenhouse, and Hothouse planetary states, the Greenhouse was the default state for the Phanerozoic climate system. Shifting the world to an Icehouse requires forcing via enhanced silicate weathering, typically generated by major continental collisional orogeny and associated positive biogeochemical feedbacks. Forcing the world from Greenhouse to Hothouse generates a HEATT episode. This requires strong LIP input to stimulate and sustain a full-fledged HEATT episode. Weaker, unsustainable, and short-lived HEATTs can be triggered by bolide impact if preconditions are favorable, but these aborted HEATT episodes leave distinctive characteristics in the record that enable them to be distinguished from fully developed and longer lasting “ideal” HEATT episodes. The long-term persistence of Hothouse conditions through the Mesoproterozoic suggests that the Hothouse planetary state was the default planetary state then, andmajor impetus was required to shift the planet out of that mode.
